["There have been fifteen total UTPs, including one in the 1920 World Series.\nAll of them involved line drives caught by infielders who then, in some order, tagged out a runner on the basepaths and then stepped on a base to retire a retreating baserunner. More often than not, one or more baserunners will have attempted to steal and will have little or no chance to retreat safely.\nBy position: shortstops have turned eight of the fifteen; second basemen have completed five; and first basemen two.\nGame 5 of the 1920 World Series featured three WS firsts: the Indians\u2019 Elmer Smith hit the first-ever World Series grand slam; ace pitcher Jim Bagby Sr. became the first pitcher to homer in a World Series; and second baseman Bill Wambsganss turned the first, and to date the last, unassisted triple play in the World Series (or any postseason game.)\n1920 World Series Game 5, Brooklyn Robins at Cleveland Indians, October 10, 1920 | Baseball-Reference.com\nIn the top of the fifth inning, Brooklyn got back-to-back singles from Pete Kilduff and Otto Miller. Dodgers pitcher Clarence Mitchell came to bat and hit a line drive to second; Wambsganss caught it, touched second base before Kilduff could make it back to second, then tagged out Kilduff before he could retreat to first base. Unassisted triple play.\nWambsganss was interviewed in Lawrence Ritter\u2019s 1966 classic The Glory of their Times:\n\"Funny thing, I played in the big leagues for 13 years, 1914 through 1926, and the only thing that anybody seems to remember is that once I made an unassisted triple play in a World Series. Many don't even remember the team I was on, or the position I played, or anything. Just Wambsganss-unassisted triple play! You'd think I was born on the day before and died on the day after.\"\nThe most recent unassisted triple play in MLB came courtesy of Phillies\u2019 second baseman Eric Bruntlett, on August 23rd, 2009; coming in the bottom of the ninth at Citi Field, it is the only game-ending unassisted triple play in MLB history.", "Uncountable triple plays that were unassisted. Watch a movie called \u2018Buffalo Sixty Six\u201d to see the extreme.", "There are various reasons. The word \u201cfans\u201d is short for \u201cfanatics\u201d which indicates an over emphasized loyalty. Some have a family tradition of supporting a particular team, usually for a team from their local residential area. Some are loyal to a particular school/college they attend or attended. Some fans identify with particular players on a team. Some are related or involved financially or community wise with a player or team unknown to the player or team. Many bet heavily on particular teams. Even if you don't use them much, you need to learn them at least to formulate an escape plan from the moves should they be used on you.\nIn a street fight, you should only use punching. Never kick and certainly don't let the fight escalate to the ground level.\nGood luck", "Streetfights and MMA are 100% exactly nothing alike.\nYou are learning to box, that is good. MMA is best won by mixing Brazilian Jujitsu with whatever you learn before it and sprinkling it with other arts their after.\nIn a streetfight, few things match a gun. Actually, the gun is really really important. Knife skills as backup are great. It is possible to get up on someone legally concealed carrying, such that they can't draw \u2026 but the knife and all other martial arts are about buying space to draw. You could be the best MMA fighter ever and a .357 or 9mm +p hit anywhere on your body will dramatically reduce your abilities (read up on shock, tunnel vision, blood leaving extremities to concentrate in the torso\u2026 which is counterproductive if you are hit there but it will take the strength outta your arms and pump it straight into that hole in your spleen) a good hit will make them moot. Anybody expecting a streetfight or even seriously the possibility, is already carrying a knife and a gun. Learn to shoot + boxing for the win. Use boxing to buy space to draw.", "Honestly, your best best is an MMA gym, not just individual arts. What gets lost sometimes on people trying to train a bunch of arts is the \u201cmixing\u201d part of MMA. Boxing in the context of a fight with kicks and grappling is alot different than standard boxing. Jiu Jitsu is different when the fight starts standing and you can get spiked, slammed, and punched,kicked, etc. Wrestling is different when you have to take a shot from striking range and when your shot can be met with a knee or a guillotine choke. So in short, a GOOD MMA gym will still teach you the individual components, but will also have some emphasis on \u201cputting it all together\u201d\nAll in all, if I had to state the MAIN individual disciplines in MMA, i\u2019d say they are boxing, muay thai, wrestling, judo, and brazilian jiu-jitsu, with some wrinkles that can be thrown in from Karate, Tae Kwon Do, etc.", "You should add a grappling skills. It could miss or be potted and then respoted ready to play through the colours in order.\nAs you mentioned this break is impossible but reasonably often a player may pot two reds in normal play. Then it is played out and scored just as it was with the mythical 15 ball break. You would get 2 points and a chance for a coloured ball as usual.", "No foul committed if only the 15 reds are potted.\nYour score would be 15 and you are then free to nominate any colour for your next pot, this colour would then be re-spotted (even if it was the yellow!) and you would then be starting the colour clearance of yellow-green-brown-blue-pink and black.\nThis also answers the age old question of \u201c\u201cwhat is the minimum points total clearance break you can make in a frame.\nThe answer is: 44\n15 reds = 15pts\nThe Yellow = 2pts\nThe colour clearance = 27pts\nThe maximum break achievable is 155. This would be compiled if you received a free ball before any reds were potted in a frame, and you were then able to take the free ball colour as a red along with a black, before commencing to compile a standard maximum break of 147.\nA good friend of mine, ex-Professional Jamie Burnett actually holds the highest ever break officially recorded in a Professional Snooker Match.\nIt was in the 2004 UK Championship when Jamie received a free ball and went on to compile a \u201c16 red\u201d clearance of 148 points.\nJamie was so focussed on winning the frame that he never even realised that he was on for having the chance to make history, until the referee called the break score of 105 with two reds left. Jamie actually questioned the referee on his call as he thought he was on 104 with two red left. The referee then repeated 105 and just stared at Jamie. It was at this point he even realised that he was on for compiling more than 147, when it dawned on him that he had started the break with a free ball.\nThis 148 target may we\u2019ll be broken at some point in the future, but due to it being very unusual, it may also stand for a long time to come.\nDuring my own playing experience, I was also involved in a best of 3 frame team match at the 2006/7 European Team Championships against England\u2019s former Professional Dean Reynolds.\nfrom my break off in the first frame, My cue ball collided with the blue, potted it and finished up 3 inches behind the green with no sight of the reds. the referee called a free ball!\ndean could have made me play again from there, but he elected to take brown as a free ball and then potted a green before taking the cue ball down the table and proceeding to make a total clearance of 143!\nThe whole room was buzzing and talking about what he had just done, I then went on a potting spree of my own in the next two frames to emerge from the match an easy 2\u20131 winner.\nthe game never ceases to amaze me!\nPS My own name is Stevie (STEPHEN) Baillie, I enjoyed many years an an amateur Snooker Player travelling the World representing my own country of Scotland playing in International events.\nSome of my best memories and friendships were made on these many trips. I wouldn\u2019t change a minute of my life even if I were able to!\ni still play snooker, but now spend a lot of time as a World Snooker and SightRight coach passing on my knowledge and experience to the new (and old) generation of snooker players.\nif you love snooker? Look me up on Facebook and say hi.", "It\u2019s within the rules to pot red/reds and then a colour. If it did happen and 15 reds somehow were pocketed, it\u2019s ok. But if you pocketed 15 reds and any colour went in a pocket with that break, then it\u2019s classed as a foul stroke.", "Impossible, but if you did and managed to keep the cueball on the bed of the table, then you score 15 points and then nominate a colour ball.", "It actually doesn\u2019t matter how many reds you pot from one stroke as long as you don\u2019t also pot a colour.", "as previous people have mentioned it is impossible to pot all 15 reds off the break. however later in the frame as the reds become more disturbed it would be theoretically possible to pot all 15 reds in one shot. it is not a foul and scores 15 points. You than nominate a colour and if potted comes up then the colours must be potted in order.", "It is impossible, because the pink is in the way of a direct power shot for starters, but even then the chances of potting all off the break are zero, given 15 reds, the 12\u2032 x 6\u2032 table dimensions and how small the pockets are, not to mention the colours in the way. Anyway, that said, theoretically, no it is not a foul, you would then nominate your colour and finish the frame of as normal. It would go viral and be one of the biggest ever hits on Youtube if it happened though!! :)", "It seems that from the break or break off any number of red balls can be potted then a nominated colour . So if a player breaks the reds and one or two are potted he then nominates a coloured ball as his next shot . Each team typically has six athletes compete in each event, with the four best scores counting toward the team score. Though it may vary from state to state, each team typically has two \u201call-around\u201d gymnasts who compete in all four events, while other gymnasts round out the lineup in their best events. The specific judging and scoring criteria for each event and how a meet is conducted is in the annual rule book that the National Federation of State High School Associations publishes. He got a few extra opportunities due to his popularity, but he earned that popularity. Plenty of guys have done that. Mike Tyson didn\u2019t deserve a title shot after he got out of jail based on beating Peter McNeeley and Buster Mathis Jr., and he didn\u2019t really earn his title shot against Lennox Lewis, either. And giving 29 year old champion Evander Holyfield a helluva fight in 1991 at age 42, and KO-ing Michael Moorer-who had taken Holyfield\u2019s title-at age 45 cemented his reputation of invincibility. At 45 years old (almost 46), was able to become the oldest heavyweight champion of the world, successfully defending the belts 3 times and only losing at almost 49.\nOverall, he went 40-3 in his second run. Many of his victories were achieved against sub-par fighters (especially during the first years of this second tenure), but it is still a remarkable record for a boxer that, in theory, had long passed is good at sports, than it is not racist.\nIf you tell Venus or Serena Williams they are good at tennis, that is not racist.\nIf you are telling some random black guy that all black guys are good at sports, than you are making generalizations based on the amount of melanin in their skin that may have no connection with reality.\nIf you\u2019ve seen the person you are speaking to play a sport, and he (or she) plays it well, than if they find that racist they are misunderstanding your point, (that he, as an individual, is playing that sport well, or at least better than you could) or are overly sensitive.", "Imagine me, but as a black person. I don\u2019t play sports, I don\u2019t go jogging, I move when I need to go to work, have chores to do, or play with my son.\nI am not good at sports.\nBut, if you came up to me, saw the color of my skin, and said that I am good at sports, that is a racial stereotype. It diminishes who I am as an individual and reduces me to nothing but a skin color with characteristics I don\u2019t even have.\nIt is judging me (positively or negatively, it doesn\u2019t matter) before you actually know me. Worse, you\u2019re misjudging me.\nWhen I don\u2019t live up to your standards of being \u201cgood at sports\u201d would I then be less black? That doesn\u2019t make sense.\nToss away the racial stereotypes and learn that each person has their own personal set of characteristics, and that the color of their skin hardly ever has anything to do with it.\nIt might matter if I were to join the Congressional Black Caucus. Otherwise, it\u2019s not really relevant to my life except how other people treat me. Which is their problem.\nNow, imagine me as a white person. You won\u2019t need much imagination, since I am.\nWhat are white people good at? Country music? Square dancing? Wearing lederhosen?\nI don\u2019t do any of those things.\nAgain, assigning someone qualities based on their skin color is stupid.", "It\u2019s actually all in the way you say it and what context you\u2019re saying it in. Let me tell you a story about a truly racist person who was once my friend (right up until the moment he said this, then I was done with him.)\nHe told me that he sees the world as a multi-player role playing game and each \u201crace\u201d of people (in quotes here because the leading theories in the field are that, physiologically, race doesn\u2019t really exist. We\u2019re all pretty much the same with minor differences in melanin production and hair texture. That\u2019s it. Of course, socially there is a huge difference in the way people are treated because of these minor physical differences.) has their own unique abilities. He then continued to say that Black people are \u201cphysically superior\u201d to other races, which is why they \u201cmake better atheletes and don\u2019t feel as much pain\u201d while white people are \u201cintellectually superior\u201d which is why they are better equipped to be in leadership positions. Please remember that these are not my opinions, I am sharing them to help teach a lesson.\nThis guy truly believed that he was not being racist or offensive, he thought he was being complimentary and realistic. What he didn\u2019t realize is that he was spouting the exact same kind of rhetoric that was used to justify Black slavery. He was making sweeping, generalized statements without any research or facts. He was being racist.\nIf you said to someone \u201cYou\u2019re Black so you must be good at sports.\u201d That\u2019s racist, even if you think that telling someone they\u2019re good at sports is a compliment, it\u2019s racist. You\u2019re relying on stereotypes to pigeonhole an entire group of people into one false concept of who they are, you are delegitimizing all the other wonderful facets that make a person a unique and complicated individual.\nIf, however, you watched a Black friend play a round of golf, or a game of soccer, baseball, or whatever other sport they\u2019re interested in and they performed well you could say, \u201cWow, not only are you good at your job/an excellent parent/the best friend a guy could have you\u2019re also a pretty talented golfer/soccer/baseball player! You must practice a lot to get so good! Congratulations!\u201d And that\u2019s not racist. That is complimenting something about someone that you have real tangible evidence of, while also promoting the fact that that thing they\u2019re good at isn\u2019t the only facet of their complicated life. You are not generalizing about them based on the colour of their skin, you are uplifting them based on the hard work and years of practice they\u2019ve put into being talented at the thing they love.\nRemember that at the end of the day, it\u2019s 100% not about you. If you say something that was intended as a compliment and that person\u2019s response is to tell you it\u2019s inappropriate or racist to say something like that then just apologize. Football technically loses money at many FBS and most FCS schools, but the advertising increases student awareness (especially when the team is good) that increases applications and alumni and other donor money. Unless you are an Ivy League School; the science building isn't getting a naming donor from an actual scientist.\nOther than the lose of most Spring games and Pro Days; college football had been largely unaffected. If anything, ESPN and the conference networks like Big Ten and Longhorn have shown more older football games then ever (and likely have better ratings than a live softball game). By the fall; the likely impact is few, if any, game cancellations and none in the SEC where \u201cIt just means more.\u201d Of the Power 5, maybe Syracuse and Rutgers has issues but everything else should be good to go. Will they be playing to empty houses? Likely to start. Most have given something or put their name to some event. Who will get pressured; the other sports.\nBasketball lost half a billion dollars from the cancellation of March Madness and Conference Tournaments. Hockey, lacrosse, and baseball/softball didn't have championships either. It's going to be a lot easier for universities to ask them for concessions (where outside The Big East and much of the ACC this is secondary marketing to the Gridiron) than football with booster pressure to protect all aspects of the program. ADs won't cut the bonuses and expenses incurred from their football program to go to the Poinsettia Bowl for a few hundred grand; asking for a salary cut might get the AD fired instead.\nThe non-revenue sports might be on the chopping block if they don't make concessions (or just cut anyways). This is going to be especially difficult for wrestling, men's aquatic sports, and rifle as these sports were already having difficulties with both receiving funding and to stay compliant with Title IX.\nAs for lost employment; are bigtime schools losing money from the virus? I imagine yes for some of the smaller D1s like those in the SWAC or Big East, but I'm not so sure about the Alabamas, Ohio States, or USCs of the world. The State Universities are still getting State/ Federal money and i haven't heard of any cuts to those programs. Most big universities, public or private, contract out things like food and janitorial services so they aren't taking as bad of a hit financially. Unless the student needs an actual lab; these universities are saving expenses from distance learning (I don't think colleges returned any money except maybe the dining plan and room and board). People are getting bigger, faster, and stronger every year. Coaches have the luxury of picking out not only the most athletic players, but also the hardest workers, the ones with the best attitudes, and the ones who DON\u2019T QUIT.\nNot getting your education in order is a big turn off for coaches. They want their athletes to be coach-able and intelligent in their sport, and going through schooling helps develop problem-solving skills as well as focus and perseverance.\nI didn\u2019t start athletics until I was 15. When I was 18, I still wasn\u2019t good enough to get recruited to big schools for college. While I played at a high level NAIA school, I wasn\u2019t a full time starter until my third year. Then I was a two time all American. When I persued a career playing professionally, agencies didn\u2019t want to represent me because I didn\u2019t go to a big school. I went on an exposure tour and got lucky and got a contract. Each year is still a fight to get a new contract. And I still don\u2019t even make barely 8,000 a year.\nIt\u2019s great to have big dreams but you had better be ready to do every hard thing in order to accomplish them. If you drop out of school, your athleticism is the only thing that you have going for you, and trust me, as an athlete and a college graduate, it\u2019s not enough. I still use my degree to work side jobs in order to make it possible to play the sport I love and make enough money to live on. That\u2019s a lot of professional\u2019s realities. Barely anyone goes to the NHL or NBA and makes a ton of money playing sports.\nFight hard to achieve your dream, but do that while you\u2019re going to school and you\u2019ll learn a lot about time management and perseverance. It\u2019ll make you a better prospect in the long run.", "You\u2019re fifteen. While there is nothing wrong with being fifteen, and we understand that you cannot alter your age, do yourself a gigantic favor and stay in school and finish it. Your \u201cwish to become an athlete\u201d while admirable, has some problems, the biggest of them the fact that very, very few make it to the professional athlete club.\nThere is no reason you cannot stay in high school and \u201cbecome an athlete\u201d along with going to school. Lots and lots of athletes pursue other careers after they retire from sports. Sports is not a career for most athletes, it is just something that they do in their prime, and in many cases their prime is five years or less, after which they have to get a \u201creal job\u201d and face reality. Go back to your school and take classes, plan a career, not just that you\u2019re quitting high school to become an athlete. Seriously. I\u2019m sure there were times when I did duck off when our team was hitting in baseball, but I can\u2019t recall needing to GO while on the field. I didn\u2019t drink a lot of water pre-game, so it wasn\u2019t ever a thought. Also I used to eat sunflower seeds a lot, which tended to have drying effects on me (the salt seemed to take up a lot of my fluid). In game I would drink water or Gatorade, but when you are expending fluids through sweat, you\u2019re simply replacing them.\nBaseball players go when their teams are at bat - there is usually a restroom very near the dugout in pro stadiums.\nBasketball players will just wait until halftime. If it\u2019s that big a deal, they\u2019ll usually run back with a trainer so people think they\u2019re just getting taped up.\nNFL players can go inside the blue tent they can put up for injuries. AND they want the money the team will generate because people coming to home games go to local businesses and that generates tax income. To get a team they have to bid for one. Sure, they get paid many millions of dollars to do this, but what they are paid in salaries is less than half of the revenue collected by the leagues.\nNo players means no games, so shouldn\u2019t they be paid according to the revenue that the league collects? People complain about this all the time, but the NFL is a big business and its players get over 45% of the league revenue. This criticism often comes from people in other countries - like, say, Australia, where the much poorer leagues of Australian Rules Football pay their own players something like only 30% of revenue.\nIt is the owners - the billionaires - who are making money from corporate welfare. You can make the argument that the league could simply fold and the players would be completely out of a job, but time has proven that this is a mutual relationship. Players are necessary for the game, and when the best players aren\u2019t on the field, fewer people will watch. Leagues can and do try to reduce player salaries, but when the league teams are independent and legally subject to anti-trust laws, they can\u2019t dictate terms to players as they have in the past.\nOne thing you should look at is the average length of career, and how many players are making closer to the league minimum, rather those star players who are making tens of millions per season. Plagues and pandemics played a role in that.", "Why shouldn't the owners who benefit pay for the stadiums?\nAthletes play a few years and then are gone, why should they or you taxpayers pay?", "Kind of like corporate welfare, isn\u2019t it? As a sad example, take a look at AOC not wanting to grant Amazon a tax break. Who is really the loser in that? Is it Amazon or is it all prospective employees and outside vendors, hotel and restaurant businesses and their employees, etc.? Or is it property owners who watch that decision adversely affect the value of their real estate?\nThese stadiums an arenas are huge to your local and state residents. It\u2019s trickle down in the most obvious and effective way. You must consider all jobs directly created and those collaterally supported by these stadiums and arenas and the beneficial effect they have in their community and state.\nI would like to say, and I mean just a little disrespect, but it\u2019s almost funny how people question the use of their taxpayer money that results in a benefit to everyone, everywhere, yet, these same taxpayers accept without complaint, the useless programs that their money is spent on that actually ruin their economy and the individual. It\u2019s a joke and a bad one at that.\nSuffice to say, IMHO, you invest in your community and state much to their benefit when you use your money to build anything that creates and supports jobs, adds pride to the community and houses great and wholesome entertainment for the whole family.", "Most stadiums are municipally owned and are usually used for several sports and other types of entertainment. Some cities have recently taken a hard stand and forced private team owners to pay for stadiums, like the new Rams/Chargers stadium in Inglewood. Staples Center in downtown LA is another example, owned not by the teams but by Anschutz Entertainment Group (AEG) which does not own a team that plays in Staples but does own professional teams in Denver and elsewhere. Staples is used by two pro basketball teams, one hockey team and is used for college tournaments. It is used on non sporting nights for some type of entertainment throughout the year. There is no push to have players somehow subsidize stadiums, that is the responsibility of owners and local governments.", "I don\u2019t know about fair or not fair. Having a Sports Stadium nearby helps the local economy by bringing all kinds of business to the area. When a team is looking to build a new stadium local governments from all over ask them to build in their town. Since multiple places are trying to get the stadium built in their town it creates a competition where the sports team gets to ask the potential cities for incentives. The city that offers the best incentives gets the stadium built in their town.\nSometimes the economic benefits of the increased business pays the city back in revenue more then what it had to pay to convince the team to build quickly and sometimes in increased revenue never quick comes as promised.\nSo the reason is because the elected officials (people your community elected because it believes in their judgement) believed it would have an overall positive impact on the community and would be worth the cost.", "How about we just refuse to pay for new professional sports venues? Our perception of a sprinter workout: put on shades, shoot some hoops,run a couple 3/4 speed 100\u2019s, shoot hoops, practice baton relay, kick back in the bleachers and wait for the distance guys to return from a 10 miler. I had great respect for their speed and I could appreciate their view of distance. They could not run a marathon and my 100m time looked like a marathon pace to them. It was all in good fun. So in 2004, when they were mounting their comeback against the Yankees, I was glued to the tiny TV in my bedroom, long after the rest of the house went to sleep, watching in amazement as the Red Sox clawed their way back. I was at my office the preceding Monday when the city was rocked by terrorist bombings at the Boston Marathon. The city had more or less been on lockdown since Friday, with baseball being cancelled as an afterthought while the suspects were hunted and finally the threat ended. They keep trading serves until one player wins 2 games in a row from a tie score (e.g., 10\u20138). It makes most sense to uphold this tradition at the French because players often get more chances to break serve on this slower clay surface.\nThe US Open is on the opposite end of the spectrum. For a very long time, the US Open has always mandated a 7-pt tiebreaker at the end of any 6\u20136 set. The tiebreaker is an American invention and first adopted in American tournaments so this is also appropriate.\nJust this year, the Australian Open has mandated a 10-point tiebreaker at the end of a tied final set. Personally for me this is better than a 7 point tiebreaker because it's less likely the breaker will be determined by one or two shots.\nFinally, Wimbledon has reluctantly bowed to popular demand and have instituted a 7 pt tiebreaker if the score becomes knotted at 12\u201312 in the final set. In other words, at 6\u20136 players play as normal but there is a limit to how long taking turns serving complete games will go. The match will end with a tiebreaker at 12-all. That is the absolute farthest the match can go.\nSo, the maximum number of games breaks down as follows,\nThe US Open and AO, 13 games maximum (7\u20136)\nWimbledon, 25 games max (13\u201312)\nAnd the French Open: Infinite"], "topic_list": ["Tennis Players", "Tennis", "Sports", "Games"], "view_list": [52], "create_time": "Apr 21, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Catherine Doucer", "upvote_list": [3], "question_title": "How many games are in a 5th set in tennis?", "respond_collected": 1, "no_of_view": "491", "name_list": ["Matt McGee"], "date_list": ["Apr 23, 2020"]}, "392": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["Wrestling (sport)", "Defecation", "Feces", "Sports", "Life Advice"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "Apr 22, 2020", "no_of_follower": 0, "question_author": "Anonymous", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "How do I keep from getting poop on my wrestling singlet?", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": "232", "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "1242": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["error"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "", "no_of_follower": 0, "question_author": "", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "error", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": 0, "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "435": {"ans_list": ["Gravity causes you to accelerate downwards at 9.8m/s\u00b2\nThat means if you're moving up with a velocity of 9.8m/s, then you'll lose that velocity in one second. If you're moving up with a velocity of 4.9m/s\u00b2, then you'll lose that in half a second.\nThat's all there is. A gymnast can put a force greater than their weight (which is not the same as mass) so that they accelerate upwards, and then when they let go, their upward velocity reduces and they start accelerating downwards.", "Gymnastics does not defy laws of gravity in no way, all you need to do a successful flip is a little bit of practice and some sense of physics.\nLet me break down the steps body moves closer to the center of mass, the moment of inertia decreases, causing the body to spin faster.\nLastly, land.\nNow, open your body to lower the angular velocity of your body, and make sure So we can just compare his first 9 seasons to Trout\u2019s as a starting point. Note that this covers ages 21\u201329 for Bonds, and 19\u201327 for Trout.\nBonds has quite respectable numbers over that period. 276 doubles, 41 triples, and 259 HR with 309 steals and 39 SB. There are 13 players who have topped those doubles/HR/steals numbers in their careers. All of them except Carlos Beltran, Bobby Bonds, and Steve Finley are in the Hall of Fame. If you loosen it to 250 HR and 300 SB in the first ten years, the list drops to two: Barry and Bobby Bonds (265/364).\nBonds put up 66.4 WAR in his first 9 seasons. That\u2019s really good. #6 all time, in fact. The names on the list ahead of him are Ted Williams (despite missing 3 seasons to the war!), Albert Pujols, Willie Mays, Mickey Mantle, and\u2026.Mike Trout.\nTrout is #3, otherwise the list is in the order I gave above. Williams 75.4, Pujols 73.8, Trout 72.8, Mays 68.1, Mantle 67.9, Bonds 66.4. That\u2019s not a huge margin; it\u2019s about 3/4 of a win per season.\nBut then you have to look back at age: Bonds is two years older. If you look at them both through their age-27 seasons, Bonds drops to 50.3.\nSo yes, Trout has been significantly better than Bonds to this point in their careers.\nBTW, Trout is at 251 doubles, 46 triples, 285 HR and 200 steals. If you plug those 2B/HR/SB totals in, it\u2019s not as exclusive as the Bonds group. There are 29 players who have exceeded those for a career. Most people say Ali could win and outspeed Tyson, but this was my point to a knocker of Tyson and an Ali fan:\nI know you\u2019re not moving on your position on Tyson\u2026It\u2019s easy to pick holes in almost anyone if you want to, Ali had loads of lousy fights, boring fights because he didn\u2019t have the power to get the job done. That fact alone does it for me, but we\u2019ll agree to disagree. Foreman was a clumsy oaf pretty much devoid of boxing skill just very heavy handed, none of the skill/speed/accuracy of Tyson. Mike may not have had the warriors spirit in him I\u2019ll grant you that, but he did get up against Lewis but was stopped on his feet, he did get up against Buster Douglas but was stopped on his feet he wasn\u2019t a complete melt. If you\u2019re good enough you can make your opponents look like \u2018tomato cans\u2019 and Tyson\u2019s bad losses came in the 2000\u2019s when he was clearly completely washed up and just fighting in order to pay the tax man (same as Holmes was when he fought Tyson). We are talking prime 86\u201389 Tyson who rightfully instilled fear in his opponents. If you want to be picky, Tyson never got dropped heavily by a guy weighing 13 stone and nearly beaten and needed his corner to cheat with the glove tear, that Angelo Dundee has freely admitted to. I\u2019m talking Cooper, if he didn\u2019t have weak eye skin that tore just to look at it, he had Ali in serious trouble in their first meeting. Tyson didn\u2019t get his jaw broke twice because he was trying to be flash by pulling his head back from a shot rather than slipping or blocking it and got chinned good and proper in an amateurish way on a number of occasions. I know the story but it proves he\u2019s not as elusive as he was made out to be. It\u2019s easy to make a legend if you \u2018highlight\u2019 their career. Tyson makes the highlight reel regularly, Ali does not and he fought plenty of mugs in his time too. Says enough for me. Anyway, let the people decide!", "I found two compilations that'll ultimately determine who has the fastest hand and foot speed.\nThe first is \u201cThe Greatest\u201d:\nThe second is \u201cIron\u201d Mike:\nWatch and judge for yourself. Hope this helps.", "As far as hand speed is concerned, prime Ali had the fastest hands of any HW ever. This is actually a scientific fact whereby his handspeed had been clocked & documented as the fastest. Probably the fastest HW punch ever thrown was the \u201cphantom\u201d punch which Ali \u201cdropped\u201d Liston with in their rematch way back in \u201865. Ali himself called this weak looking punch his \u201canchor\u201d punch but it was delivered like a bolt of lightning & was comfortably faster than the blink of an eye.\nIn terms of handspeed, the Iron Man was also a speed demon but he generally gets rated as the 3rd fastest HW in history- Floyd Patterson being the 2nd fastest. So Ali has a slight edge in terms of handspeed.\nIn terms of foot speed, I think it is almost too close to call. Tyson generally gets rated as the no.1 gap closer of the modern HW era & in this respect , I think he is in a league of his own. Ali\u2019s best footwork was more often than not defensive footwork & was designed primarily to keep him out of harms way. So it is a difficult & somewhat unfair comparison - Tyson\u2019s aggressive footwork vs Ali\u2019s defensive footwork\u2026\u2026.Certainly the most spectacular display of footwork ever was the Ali shuffle, particularly in his finest hour vs Cleveland \u201cBig Cat\u201d Williams.\nIn this fight, Ali was believed to be almost untouchable & his footwork was dazzling to say the least.\nWatching prime Tyson jump rope was also an awe inspiring sight. 16 stone guys don\u2019t usually defy the law of gravity so easily. A well known American boxing writer once described prime Tyson as the boxing equivalent of Baryshnikov. In terms of P4P foot speed, I think it\u2019s dead even, given that Tyson was the more muscular & heavier guy.", "From a functional stand point. Ali did.\nTyson was explosive and put more of his body into his punches, Ali was fluid and efficient.\nBeing explosive however, is a give away in boxing, the best guys will see the punches coming or brace for them at least. Smooth punches don't allow your oponents to react as easy, since there isn't as much tell. This is why Ali was hitting oponents so easy, especially in his prime, but in truth his entire career. He was beating high level boxers in the 70s and really wasn't athletically all there.", "I would say Ali (when he was actually Clay), but Tyson is a lot closer in hand speed than people would give him credit for.\nBoth had great footwork, but in different ways. (I don\u2019t even know if \u201cspeed\u201d is a thing when it comes to footwork.) Boxing is a lot like playing the drums or the piano. What you are doing with your hands has to work independently of what you are doing with your feet. You can concentrate on what your hands are doing, but your footwork needs to be automatic. If you have to think about it, you\u2019ll probably get hit.\nA lot of fighters, even successful ones, never develop their footwork. This was exploited by both Ali and Tyson. You could see it every time Ali would change direction and his opponent would look like an idiot. Tyson was a master of cutting off the ring and stepping inside on guys. He would do those little dips with his shoulders to avoid a punch, but whenever he did that he would take a step forward. He really knew how to make a guy pay for it when he missed.\nLarry Holmes had a great move where he would lean back on the ropes to avoid a punch, then step to the right and throw his right hand. He had great feet as well.\nActually, one of the things that used to drive me crazy were guys who always seemed to end the round in their corner. I never figured it out. There was a guy I fought a few times and I swear every time a round ended, he would stand there and look at me for a minute and then take a seat, while I had to walk across the ring to my corner. Ali was really good at that. I still don\u2019t know how the hell someone can have that kind of awareness, but that may also have been something they did intentionally when they sparred.\nThe guy with the greatest footwork ever was Ray Robinson. But he was the closest thing we ever had to a perfect fighter. Ali patterned his entire career after him.", "I\u2019ve been around a while. His jab actully covered the distance on 4/100 of a second which is a blink of an eye.\nPrime Ali was just to quick it was like watching an old Bruce lee movie where the cameras weren\u2019t quick enough to see his punches.\nTyson was fast don\u2019t get me wrong but Ali was quicker.\nTyson\u2019s punches though where just perfection to watch he practiced combs in the mirror when he was younger. Johnson", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1], "question_title": "Are the coronavirus \"safe sports\" that should be permitted despite the lockdowns and stay in shelter warnings?", "respond_collected": 6, "no_of_view": "1,800", "name_list": ["Sharon Jones Smith", "Andrea Bianconi", "Bill Zhang", "Michael Lee", "Jamie Lombardo", "Diane Sypnier"], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020", "Apr 28, 2020"]}, "1465": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["error"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "", "no_of_follower": 0, "question_author": "", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "error", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": 0, "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "205": {"ans_list": ["Very important is the ergonomics of the draw force curve. Many (all?) people can store the most energy when the force rises fairly quickly, in a few inches, from start to max draw weight and then, maybe after a few inches, drops slowly until the letoff point.\nThis matches a typical person\u2019s strength for the different positions that there arms are in while drawing a bow.\nThis is also why shooting a recurve is so much harder. With a recurve you are holding the max draw weight at full draw and most all people are not at their strongest in that position.", "Your maximum draw weight is determined by a combination of size, strength, technique, and bow design. Your size determines how much strength you have to work with, and your technique how much of that strength you can actually apply to drawing the bow. Some bows are harder to draw than others.\nMark Stretton holds the modern world record for drawing a heavy 200 pound war bow. He\u2019s not a small man, but there are bigger and stronger men who could not draw that bow.\nJoe Gibbs has the record for shooting a heavy war arrow the farthest, over 300 yd. He shoots heavy 170 pound longbows and recurves. There are smaller and bigger men who can lift more weight, but can\u2019t draw the bows he can.\nKhatuna Lorig is an Olympic target archery champion. She uses a 52 pound bow for target archery, a weight heavier than some bigger, stronger men use for target shooting or hunting.\nBow design makes some bows easier or harder to draw at the same weight. Some bows will cast the same arrows faster and/or farther at lower draw weights than heavier bows. Shorter bows have a sharper string angle that can pinch the fingers together more as you near the end of the draw stroke. Drawing with the thumb can eliminate that problem. How the draw weight builds during the draw stroke can make a heavier bow seem lighter, or a lighter bow heavier. A bow with a steady, even draw force curve can feel easier than a bow that \u201cstacks\u201d the weight in the middle or at the end. Modern compound bows with pulleys and cams build to a peak, then drop off so you are holding less weight at full draw. It might take 70 pounds to draw the bow, but only 15 pounds to hold it at full draw. An 82 pound Manchu bow builds more weight in the middle of the draw stroke but does not drop off. It can feel heavier to draw than a 100 pound longbow, but cast the same arrow faster than a 125 pound longbow.\nRecurves cast arrows faster and farther than longbows of the same draw weight. The distance record for Modern American Longbow Unlimited is 546 yds. For the Field Bow Unlimited the record is 706 yds. The fastest and farthest anyone has ever cast an arrow with a hand held Conventional Flight bow is over 500 fps and 1336 yds by Don Brown with a 135 pound recurve flight bow and a very light flight arrow. That\u2019s even farther than the Compound Flight unlimited record of 1320 yds.\nIn the medieval period hunting bows were less than 80 pounds, target and trick bows even lighter. The sport bows of today are lighter than the sport bows of yesterday.\nThe heaviest war bows we know of are the English war bows found on the ship the Mary Rose (185 pounds), and the Turkish and Chinese war bows documented in literature and in museum collections (240 pounds). Strong men are strong men across time and cultures.", "Leverage, not strength. Very slight archers have been known to pull very high draw weights. So, technique is needed, so that the leverage is applied. (The bones of your draw arm are used as second order levers, for example.)\nOnce one learns to apply the correct leverage, strength does matter.\nThe ideal body shape for an archer is generally fairly slender as competitive archer is an endurance sport to some extent.", "For recurve bows: Maximum draw weight is determined by 1) the strength of the limbs 2) strength of the string, and 3) how far back you pull the bowstring. For example, I have a samick sage recurve bow with 35# limbs. These limbs have a maximum safe draw distance of 36 inch. Meaning that it will take 35# of force to draw it back 36 inchs. Can you pull it further back, yes. It is not safe to do so because the limbs of the bow can only take so much but yes. The more you pull the bowstring back the more force it will have.\nFor compound bows: No, a compound bows draw weight is determined by how the mechanics of the bow it set. Without changing the settings there is nothing you can do you increase the draw weight.", "How much you can draw matters but how much are you comfortable holding back in an odd position? How much can you draw with minimum movement. It does not take real high poundage to hunt deer. 40 pounds will pass completely through a white tail deers chest. My first one I thought I missed cause i watched arrow hit the ground behind the deer shooting 50 pounds.", "Technique. If you\u2019re cranking the string with just the muscles of your draw arm, you are going to very limited in your maximum draw poundage. Learn how to put your back muscles into it, and your max pull is going to go up substantially. Figure out how to incorporate opposing force with your bracing arm and you\u2019ll up your poundage further still.\nI\u2019m a fairly strong bloke, but when I first start shooting, a 35# recurve would wear me out after three or four ends. Over time, and as my technique improved, I can pull 55# fairly easily and for quite a while. Had the pleasure of shooting a 125# war bow last year. No way I could have done that without good technique."], "topic_list": ["Bow (archery)", "Archery", "Sports"], "view_list": [35, 113, 18, 31, 34, 22], "create_time": "Apr 26, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Samuel Lee", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0], "question_title": "Is the maximum draw weight on a bow I can handle determined by nothing but sheer strength, or are there other factors too?", "respond_collected": 6, "no_of_view": "696", "name_list": ["Frank Popa", "Michael Orick", "Steve Ruis", "Chris Ehler", "Joey Bullington", "Mark Lenin"], "date_list": ["Apr 27, 2020", "Apr 26, 2020", "Apr 26, 2020", "Apr 26, 2020", "Apr 26, 2020", "Apr 26, 2020"]}, "45": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["Sporting Events", "Professional Sports", "Sports", "COVID-19 (2019-2020)"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "Apr 22, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Purusothaman P", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "What are the major sports events in the world postponed due to this coronavirus pandemic?", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": "19", "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "1305": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["error"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "", "no_of_follower": 0, "question_author": "", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "error", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": 0, "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "266": {"ans_list": ["That depends on what you define as the \u201csports world\u201d. What you can do is practice starts with both legs. Have your coach time you over 20m multiple times to see which foot forward gives you the best start.", "It will trim a couple of tenths off your time if you\u2019re lucky.", "12.5 for a 13 year old is pretty good. Changing to your dominant foot will make you quicker off the line. It should also improve your acceleration. But, there is no way of knowing for sure how much it will mean to you.\nAt 13 you should be focusing on learning how to run. You should also be working on getting stronger. My sprinters know the slogan, \u201cstrength is power, power is speed\u201d. Learn how to do the \u201cA\u201d and \u201cB\u201d skips and the \u201ccycle drill\u201d. Make sure you learn to lift with someone who really knows their way around the weightroom. Good Luck.", "I'm an ex track and field guy and most of the sprinters I trained with started with their dominant foot in the rear. The reason for this is to get more of an explosion out of the starting blocks. Pushing off with your dominant foot/leg will allow you to thrust yourself out of the starting blocks and give you your best time.\nHowever, you may have to experiment and try both ways several times. Whichever foot/leg consistently gives you the best time is the one you should go with.\nHere's another thing you may want to experiment with. I experimented with the 40 yard dash by trying three different starting positions. Btw, my right foot/leg is my dominant so I always push off with it.\nAnyways, my experiment was starting with both hands on the ground, starting with one hand on the ground and starting in the upright position with no hands on the ground. My best times were when I started in the upright position. Weird, but I guess my acceleration was better standing up than starting with my hands on the ground.\nLet us know your results in the comments.", "I am not a sprinter but have been around those that are and sprint coaches.\nI am not sure if you are using starting blocks when you state that your right is forward and left foot is back.\nI do know that those that work on starting and the \u201cbest way for them\u201d to use starting blocks - which foot is back, the distance between blocks, the angle of the blocks - try it both ways and get themselves timed for 10 or at most 20 meters.\nWhatever gives the best results or whatever gives the best feel is the right answer - foot dominance may not matter.\nAlso think of this - if your right foot is forward you are using your dominant left foot for most of your push off. Both feet do not leave the starting block at the same instant. Your back foot gives you the real push the block provide. This effect has been measured since in electronically timed runs there is a force sensor on both blocks - the back foot will leave the block an instant after the lead foot providing most of the push.\nHere are two videos analyzing Usain Bolts running mechanics\nSprint Mechanics\nSprint Start in Slow Motion"], "topic_list": ["Sprints (sport)", "100 Metres (sprint)", "Sprinting", "Track and Field", "13 (age)", "Running (activity)", "Sports", "Exercise"], "view_list": [12, 3, 42, 27, 28], "create_time": "Apr 22, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Guy Trimble", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 1, 0, 0], "question_title": "I\u2019m 13 and recently ran a 12.5 100m dash. On the right, signed by Robert D. Manfred (Jr.) as commissioner, is a 2019 ball.\nOne can feel a difference between the two, primarily in terms of hardness. The 2019 is incredibly hard, with as much give as a solid granite stone. An even better illustration is the 2017, 2018, and 2019 balls are compared:\nThey\u2019re labeled as \u201cSpring Training\u201d balls, but this signifies to us (as umpires and staff) that they are for use for Major League and AAA pitchers within the spring training time period of that year. AA and A league players use a different ball (pictured below), while international league players (such as Korean Professional, Mexican Professional, or Japanese Professional) will bring and use their own ball. I\u2019ve called games wherein, at any one time, I\u2019ve got one of four different baseballs in my ball bags.\nHere\u2019s a better, closer view of the three latest Major League baseballs (I didn\u2019t get a 2020 ball, because, obviously, COVID-19 stamped out the season):\nLook, specifically, at the seams. The threads on the 2019 ball are finer, and the gap in the seam is much tighter. Why\u2019s that? Because between the 2018 and 2019 seasons, Rawlings (which is 50% owned by MLB) undertook a substantial quality controls campaign in the production of Major League baseballs. The rubber-clad cork pills (the center core) was made more precisely, the winding of the yarn was done, robotically, more precisely, and the leather casing pieces were precision cut by a laser. The stitch holes were also \u201cshot\u201d more precisely by a laser-guided machine. As such, the entire ball was made \u201ctighter\u201d. To whit, this tighter ball brings with it a degree of fragility. The entire ball is so tight the seams look like they\u2019re under enormous tension, and are on the verge of splitting.\nThis fragility isn\u2019t a problem when the average lifespan of a Major League baseball in a game is less than five pitches. However, these baseballs, once removed or rejected from a game, are not to be used for a game again, and are actually too hard, too slick, and too tight to be used in pitching machines for batting practice. They can be used as Live batting practice balls, and while some do end up being acquired by amateur organizations, I can speak from experience, they don\u2019t hold up as well as their Minor League or lesser-league siblings:\nIn the upper left is that same 2019 Major League baseball. In the upper right is the \u201cGeneric\u201d Minor League Baseball (this one is not labeled with the specific minor league, thus, any AA or A club may use it). In the lower left is the Arizona Fall League (Rookie League) baseball. In the lower right is the \u201cRawlings Official League Baseball\u201d (which was asked about in the OQ). This particular one is labeled for use by the Dutch professional league (KBBSF\u2022FRBBS). Note how much thicker and more robust the seams are both the AZFL and ROLB baseballs. These baseballs are similar to the specification used for High School (NFHS) baseballs. Each conference in NCAA & NAIA baseball is allowed to designate their own baseball, too, but nearly all are using the same specification found in the Minor League baseball. It really is easier on a pitcher to pitch than its Major League sibling, and tends to hold up over multiple pitches, hits and impacts better. One of our NAIA conferences here uses this type of baseball, and provided the players & staff-members retrieve the foul balls, we use no more than 12\u201316 of them per 9-inning game.\nMost of our Adult Amateur leagues use the same spec as the Minor League ball. Some of the local (to Phoenix, AZ) leagues even go so far as to obtain \u201cused\u201d baseballs from the fifteen clubs that call Phoenix home, and I can tell you, hand on heart, the Minor League balls last longer than the Major League ones, besides the pitchers find the Major League ones too hard, and the seams too low, to get good bite on curves and sliders on.\n\u201cWhat is the best ball to use for fun to shag and hit some homers?\u201d\nAny, really, that are 9-in circumference, 5 oz in weight, and are a cork-&-rubber pill encased in yarn and leather. There really isn\u2019t any difference in terms of hitting; the difference is in terms of durability and pitching."], "topic_list": ["National League (baseball)", "Baseball Rules", "MLB (business)", "Baseball Pitching", "Baseball Statistics", "Balls (sports)", "Major League Baseball", "Baseball", "Sports", "Association Football"], "view_list": [205], "create_time": "Apr 23, 2020", "no_of_follower": 2, "question_author": "Sam LeMieur", "upvote_list": [1], "question_title": "What is the difference between recreational (Official league) and official (official major league) baseballs? The referee tosses a coin, one person calls it and a coin toss winner is determined. The coin toss winner can then choose whether to serve first in the first game, or to defer to the second game.\nSee rule 3.1 here; https://www.teamusa.org/usa-racquetball/rules\nIn practice, i\u2019ve seen multiple other ways used to determine first serve:\nthe players play \u201codd or even\u201d with a random number of fingers held up behind their back.\nThe Ref writes a number on the back of the score card and plays \u201codd or even\u201d with one of the players on the court (this is generally what I did)\nPlayers will \u201clag\u201d for serve; standing in the rear of the court both players will hit the ball off the front wall, and the person who lands the attempt closest to the short line wins the right to serve first.\nIn other racquet sports I\u2019ve seen \u201cup or down\u201d played with the logo on the butt of a spun racquet. I\u2019ve never seen this in racquetball, likely because racquetball racquets have tethers and players are required to keep the tethers on their wrists in the course of play."], "topic_list": ["Racquetball", "Sports"], "view_list": [16], "create_time": "Apr 22, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Philip Longee", "upvote_list": [0], "question_title": "Who serves first in racquetball?", "respond_collected": 1, "no_of_view": "505", "name_list": ["Todd Boss"], "date_list": ["Apr 23, 2020"]}, "1382": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["error"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "", "no_of_follower": 0, "question_author": "", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "error", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": 0, "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "811": {"ans_list": ["A child who tortures ants for fun and an adult who hunts for sports enjoy the same reward, their pleasure at the expense of a life with total disregard to the reality of that being that was alive.\nTo kill for sport is to make another life\u2019s worst plausible scenario a reality. "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": 0, "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "814": {"ans_list": ["You\u2019re right to cut cultural influence out of it, as there is a heavyweight who gets called the greatest more than he probably deserves, because of his sheer general lore - Mike Tyson.\nAs for Ali, his only rival for the #1 heavyweight spot, according to most every expert, is Joe Louis. In Louis\u2019s favor, he has the record for most title defenses of all time and the longest title reign, only losing once in his prime to Max Schmeling, which he avenged spectacularly. Plus, he had two past prime wins (one debated) over Jersey Joe Walcott, arguably his greatest opponent at the time.\nIn Ali\u2019s favor, however, he took the title away from two all time greats (Sonny Liston and George Foreman) and managed to win a sort of \u201ccareer for career\u201d series with a third (Joe Frazier). Louis\u2019s greatest wins are over borderline-greats at best, who would have to plead their case to make a top 20 heavyweights list. Add to that, Ali has a strong supporting resume, filled with wins over all the best contenders from the golden age of boxing (Ken Norton, Floyd Patterson, Jimmy Young, Jimmy Ellis, Ernie Terrell, Archie Moore, Zora Folley, Jerry Quarry, Ron Lyle, Earnie Shavers, Oscar Bonavena, George Chuvalo, Joe Bugner\u2026), which altogether is a match for Louis\u2019s resume by itself. So even with the extra losses (and arguably one or two more close/debatable matches than Louis had), I would have to go with Ali. But I can understand picking Louis.", "Based solely on records achieved and accomplishments in the Ring, and nothing else, Muhammad Ali is the greatest heavyweight who ever lived, with Joe Louis second.\nCREDIT PICTURE TO SPOKEMAN-REVIEW\nWhy is Ali the Greatest heavyweight in history?\nhe fought the best competition of any heavyweight, and beat more of them. He fought 18 top 100 fighters, and beat 17 of them. Joe Louis was next, with 15 top 100 opponents, but he only beat 13 of them - Ali had the best win percentage against top 100 competition of any heavyweight other than Rocky Marciano;\nhis general recognized accomplishments were greater - winning the title 10 years apart from the #4 and #19 heavyweights of all time, being the only fighter to retire and come back to regain the undisputed title, and more;\nhe never ducked, avoided, or failed to meet the best fighters of his age, and always offered vanquished foes who wanted one a rematch;\nmost experts believe his skills made him the most gifted heavyweight of all time.\nFirst, Ali fought the best competition in history\n\u201cWhen people ask me about who was the greatest of all time, I say look at the records. I fought better competition, over a longer period of time than any other fighter in history.\u201d (Ali himself quoted in \u201cThe Greatest\u201d)\nAngelo Dundee, Ali's and Sugar Ray Leonard's trainer, said; \"look at Ali\u2019s quality of opposition. He shook up the world against Liston, then did it again. He shocked the world against Foreman. He won two out of three against Frazier. Same against Ken Norton. He beat Patterson twice. The also-rans on Ali\u2019s record\u2014Jerry Quarry, Ron Lyle, Zora Folley, Oscar Bonavena, Bob Foster, Ernie Terrell\u2014were as good as all but two or three opponents Joe Louis beat during his 11 years as champ.\"\nBBC boxing writer and historian Ben Dirs said of Ali compared to Wlad Klitschko and other fighters of this generation, \"Ali reigned in the most talent-rich era of heavyweight boxing, winning the title from the fearsome Sonny Liston in 1964, winning it again from the even more fearsome George Foreman 10 years later and beating greats such as Floyd Patterson, Joe Frazier and Ken Norton in between.\"\nAli met great punchers and beat them:\nRon Lyle, Earnie Shavers and George Foreman\nAli met great boxers and beat them:\nJimmy Ellis, Floyd Patterson, Zora Folley, Jimmy Young\nAli met great boxer/punchers and beat them:\nSonny Liston.\nAli met the greatest swarmer of them all, and beat him twice:\nJoe Frazier\nTo quote Ali, \"I whopped them all!\"\nIn his book \"Going the Distance,\" Ken Norton said, \"out of all the fighters I was in with, Frazier, Foreman, Holmes, Ali was the best.\" Not only that, Ken said, \"he was the best I ever saw, period.\"\nLet us look at the numbers and examine who Ali met in the ring:\nAnthony Mason, boxing writer, said \"I think the only way to fairly rank a boxer's place in history is by comparing their r\u00e9sum\u00e9s. And that does not mean just wins and losses - it is too easy today to fight only has beens or never will be's, and run up the record.\u201d\nAli faced 18 top 100 heavyweights, and beat all but one, and when he was 39 and ill\n#2 Archie Moore (ranked as light-heavyweight but fought for heavyweight title twice)\n#4 Sonny Liston\n#13 Joe Frazier\n#14 Larry Holmes\n#15 Floyd Patterson\n#19 George Foreman\n#20 Bob Foster (ranked as light heavyweight but fought for heavyweight title twice)\n#22 Cleveland Williams\n#28 Eddie Machen\n#34 Ken Norton\n#36 Zora Folley\n#43 Henry Cooper\n#44 Ernie Terrell\n#48 Jimmy Ellis\n#51 Karl Mildenberger\n#57 Oscar Bonavena\n#67 Jerry Quarry\n#68 Ron Lyle\nAli faced 18 top 100 all time heavyweights in 26 fights, he beat 17 of the 18 at least once, 5 of them twice!\nAdd in #116 Joe Bugner, #118 Doug Jones, #124 Jimmy Young, #131 Mac Foster, #141 Earnie Shavers, and Ali faced 23 fighters in the top 150 and beat 22 of them at least once in 31 fights! That is by far the best competition faced and beaten in heavyweight history.\nIn comparison, to Ali beating 17 of 18 top 100 fighters, 5 of them twice, Joe Louis fought 15 top 100 heavyweights in 17 fights, beating 13 of them at least once, and beat only one twice. Joe only faced 16 in the top 150 to Ali\u2019s 23.\nThere is just no comparing anyone else\u2019s record of meeting and beating the best to Ali\u2019s.\nSecond, his total accomplishments are the best in heavyweight history\nMuhammad faced and defeated two of the most intimidating fighters in history, Sonny Liston at 22 years old, Fight City\u2019s most intimidating fighter in history, and then defeated Big George Foreman, #5 most intimidating fighter in history, a decade later at 32. These two are also called the two strongest fighters to ever enter the ring according to Johnny Tocco, who worked with Foreman, Tyson and Sonny Liston, said of the three, Liston hit the hardest, and was the strongest, with Foreman second over Tyson.\nAnd Ali beat them both, the #4 and #19 all time heavyweights, ten years apart!\nAli is the first and only three-time lineal World Heavyweight Champion.\nAli was and remains the first World Heavyweight Champion to come back from retirement and regain the undisputed title.\nAli beat 14 world champions, from the years 1962 to 1978, over an incredible 16 year period.\nAli won twenty-two World Heavyweight Championship fights over a 14 year period.\nAli made a total of nineteen successful title defenses of the undisputed title, nine during his first reign and ten during his second reign, second only to Joe Louis.\nAnother record he set which stands today, he has a record of 11-0 in rematches. Ali faced a heavyweight record of 8 Hall of Fame fighters, winning all but one, and making 11 total fights against Hall of Famers.\nAll eight of the Hall of Famers who faced him said he was the greatest heavyweight who ever lived, including Hall of Famer Larry Holmes, who fought him when Ali was 39 and ill.\nAli was named Ring \"Fighter of the Year\" for 1963, 1966, 1972, 1974, 1975 and 1978. Ali was named the Boxing Writers Association of America \"Fighter of the Year\" for 1965, 1974 and 1975. Ali was named Sports Illustrated \"Sportsman of the Year\" for 1974. Ali was named The Ring \"Fighter of the Decade\" for the 1970s. Ali was inducted into the U.S. Olympic Hall of Fame in 1983. He received the Boxing Writers Association of America James J. Walker Memorial Award for 1984.\nAli was inducted into the World Boxing Hall of Fame in 1986. He was inducted into the The Ring Boxing Hall of Fame in 1987. Ali was inducted into the International Boxing Hall of Fame in 1990. Ali was named \"Athlete of the Century\" by GQ magazine in 1998. He was named \"Sports Personality of the Century\" by the BBC in 1999, and \"Sportsman of the 20th Century\" by Sports Illustrated in 1999.\nThird, Ali never ducked or avoided anyone\nAli fought every single top contender during his title reign, every, single, one.\nAli offered rematches to those he had defeated, and the only titlist who he did not rematch, George Foreman, had been offered a rematch, but lost to the #2 contender and retired.\nFinally, most experts believe his skills were the best of all the heavyweights, ever\nMike Tyson, a student of boxing to this day, and a guy who has probably watched more boxing film than any other boxing historian, said of fighting Ali:\n\u201cNobody beats Ali,\u201d Mike said when asked if he\u2019d have beaten him, prime against prime.\nAnd Mike explains that those who grew up in the \u201980s and \u201990s and perceived Tyson as the winner just because he hit harder and had bigger muscles let themselves be fooled by Ali\u2019s physical appearance. \u201cAli is a fuckin\u2019 animal,\u201d Tyson said. \u201cHe looks more like a model than a fighter, but what he is, he\u2019s like a Tyrannosaurus Rex with a pretty face. And fast, Lord God he was fast!\u201d\nBut could you have beaten him on your best day, the reporter said?\n\u201cNOBODY beats Ali,\u201d Mike emphasized, saying Ali was simply too fast, and too skilled.\nIn the May 5, 1969 issue of Sports Illustrated, Ali\u2019s jab was measured with an omegascope. Ali\u2019s jab, it was found, could smash a balsa board 16.5 inches away in 19/100 of a second. It actually covered the distance in 4/100 of a second, which is the blink of an eye.\nHis phenomenal speed in his prime never ceases to amaze people who saw him in person, or even on TV, or who have studied him later on film. The late Jimmy Jacobs, then the owner of the world's largest fight film collection, once also measured Ali's jab by an omegascope against every other fighter he had in his collection - and he had tape on every fighter who had ever been filmed.\nAli\u2019s jab was not only faster than any heavyweight of all time - including Larry Holmes by a wide margin, but Jacobs found that Ali was faster than any middleweight he measured - for instance, Sugar Ray Robinson's jab took 8.5 frames of film. Ali's took only 6.5!\nCREDIT COX\u2019S CORNER MONTE COX\nCanadian heavyweight George Chuvalo said in Ring of Ali\u2019s speed, \"my plan for the fight was simple: as the shorter guy, I wanted to stay close to Ali, nullify his speed and prevent him from using the whole ring. I also wanted to make it rough. The rougher, the better. But it took all of about 30 seconds for me to realize he was the fastest fighter I\u2019d ever seen. It\u2019s one thing to expect it; it\u2019s another thing to feel it, live it.\"\n\"You can't hit him,\" said Cleveland Williams, \"you just cannot hit him!\" According to CompuBox, Williams landed only 10 punches the entire fight. Williams said \"I threw hooks, I threw uppercuts, I missed them all! Hell, I couldn't even land a jab!\"\nZora Folley, after facing Ali, said \"you can't hit him! But he sure can hit you.\"\nThe great Rocky Marciano, who filmed the \"computer fight\" with Ali in 1969 while Ali was banned from boxing, said of Ali \"the fastest man on wheels, no fighter who ever lived was that fast.\" Rocky, when asked how good he thought Ali was, said \"most would make the guy before they made him stop fighting \u2013 the fighter that destroyed Cleveland Williams, before time off took so much of the skip and slip from his legs \u2013 a strong favorite over anybody, anytime, anywhere, including me.\"\nBoxing Historian Monte Cox wrote that \u201cMuhammad Ali was the most naturally gifted heavyweight champion in history.\u201d\nThe record bears that out.\nhttp://coxscorner.tripod.com/196...\nIn his book \"Going the Distance,\" Ken Norton said, \"out of all the fighters I was in with, Frazier, Foreman, Holmes, Ali was the best.\" Not only that, Ken said, \"he was the best I ever saw, period.\"\nIn addition, mental determination, strength of will, desire, ability to adapt, all factor in to who was most skilled - and again, Ali wins. Ring IQ? His adapting on the fly against Foreman in Zaire is the poster child for ring intelligence.\nAnd inner strength? Mike Tyson spoke of Ali\u2019s mental strength and will, in a 2012 interview with Thisis50 | If it's Hot it's Here!\n, also described how Ali collapsed to the canvas after stopping Joe Frazier in their third fight in 1975. Mike said in awe \"He had too much pride. He'd rather die than let somebody beat him,\" said Tyson.\nWhen asked again who would've won between the two had they met at age 20, Tyson didn't hesitate in answering:. \"Never stopping and he\u2019s dead tired? I can\u2019t beat that man. Hell fucking no. No fucking way,\" said Tyson.\nAn example of that steely will, on the night he stunned the world and beat George Foreman, sensing the mood in his dressing room Ali asked: \u201cWhat\u2019s wrong around here? Everybody scared? Scared? A little thing like this? This is like another day in the gym.\u201d\nAli was the fastest heavyweight who ever lived, maybe the fastest fighter, period, in addition to having that indomitable will and determination Mike Tyson spoke of.\nMax Kellerman says \"From 1970, when Ali came back from his forced exile, to 1978, when Ali won back his crown for the final time (against Leon Spinks), Ali shared the very top shelf with Joe Frazier and George Foreman, and the three of them were supported by Ken Norton and Joe Bugner and, in the beginning of the decade, Oscar Bonavena, Jerry Quarry and Jimmy Ellis, and at the end of the decade Ernie Shavers, Ron Lyle and Jimmy Young. Ali fought them all, and many of the others fought each other. The greatest heavyweight era ever.\"\nConclusion:\nChuck Wepner, before he met Ali for the title, made a promise to his wife before he left for the arena. \"That night, before the title bout, I bought my wife a powder blue negligee, and I gave it to her, I said, \u2018Wear this to bed tonight, because tonight you\u2019re going to be sleeping with the heavyweight champion of the world.\u2019 Anyway, after the fight, I come back to the room, I walked in, and she\u2019s sitting on the edge of the bed in the negligee. She says, \u2018Am I going to Ali\u2019s room, or is he coming to mine?\"\n\"I came to love Ali,\u201d two-time foe Floyd Patterson told David Remnick for his book King of the World. \u201cI came to see that I was a fighter and he was history.\" Patterson went on to say. \"Before they took boxing away from him for three years, he was the best fighter who ever lived, period.\u201d\nLegendary American boxing historian and writer Bert Sugar, said of Ali, \"True greatness comes from within as well as the physical, and Ali had it all. On his best night, he beats any fighter who ever lived.\"\nLennox Lewis said \"Ali was the greatest heavyweight EVER in my opinion.... I would never put myself in his class...and never have.\"\nMax Kellerman makes the case for Ali best: \"if you count from the day he dethroned the most feared boxing champion ever, he dominated his sport for 14 years! NO one else ever did that.\"\nCREDIT TO:\nAll rankings, statistics to Boxrec\nGoing the Distance by Ken Norton\nChuck Wepner calls the day he lost to Muhammad Ali the greatest of his life\nCox\u2019s Corner and Monte Cox\nFight City \u201cTop 12 Most Intimidating Boxers\u201d by Robert Portis\nMax Kellerman and ESPN As heavyweight eras go, this one is very good\nMike Tyson and Thisis50 | If it's Hot it's Here!\n,\nMuhammad Ali: A Life by Thomas Hauser\nMuhammad Ali: A View From the Corner by Dr. Ferdie Pacheco\nThe Devil and Sonny Liston by Nick Tosches\nThe Greatest: My Own Story by Muhammad Ali", "It\u2019s still Ali. He had the best quality of opposition of any heavyweight champion, and comes off looking pretty good from a quantity perspective, as well. He won 2 of 3 from Frazier (whom he probably would have prevented from ever becoming Champion in the first place if he hadn\u2019t been banned in his prime), 2 of 3 from Ken Norton (who really performed especially well against Ali, with all three fights being arguable), and went undefeated against the likes of Sonny Liston, George Foreman, and Floyd Patterson, just to name the fellow Champions.\nHe slipped up and lost to the mediocre Leon Spinks as he was on his way out, but even then he won the rematch by a wider margin than he lost the first.\nThe only guys he ever ended up second-best to were future Champion Larry Holmes and future titlist Trevor Berbick, but both of those were after coming out of a retirement he most certainly should have stuck with, as he was already neurologically declining.\nAnd then there\u2019s the eyeball test. Watch him against Liston or Patterson or most any of his fights in the 60s, and with a trained eye it will become obvious that very few heavyweights in history have the tools to consistently compete with him in his prime. He\u2019s way too fast and way too in control of distance for many guys to get much done against him at that point in his career.", "Ali is \u201cKing of the Ring\u201d too. He beat Archie Moore, Henry Cooper, Floyd Patterson, Sonny Liston, George Foreman, Joe Frazier, Ken Norton, Ron Lyle, Earnie Shavers, Joe Bugner, Jerry Quarry, Oscar Bonavena-a heavyweight hall of fame. Ali defeated all of his opponents except Holmes and Berbick who he never should have been liscenced to fight-because he was already sick with Parkinson\u2019s. He was 11\u20130 in rematches. No one else faced the murderer\u2019s row of opposition that he did and came out a winner. He won the title 3 times between 1964\u20131978. Rocky Marciano-who retired undefeated-only had 6 title defenses. Ali had 22. And 3 of Marciano\u2019s defenses were against light-heavyweights-175 lbs-2 against Ezzard Charles and one against Archie Moore. Moore had Marciano on the floor in the 2nd round of their title fight. He KO\u2019d Jersey Joe Walcott at 38 and Joe Louis at 37 afte he\u2019d been retired 2 years. Marciano never beat a champion under 33 years old. MIke Tyson, Evander Holyfield, Lennox Lewis-all great champions-none can say they faced the Murderer\u2019s row that Ali did. You have to look at quality of opposition. For example-some people say Floyd Mayweather is the best welterweight because he\u2019s \u201cUndefeated\u201d. But he cherry-picked his opponents, ducked anyone who could beat him, and for his \u201cRecord Breaking\u201d 50th fight picked a guy who\u2019d never had an amateur or pro boxing match in his life. And it took Floyd 10 rounds to beat him. Not the 70\u2032s version of Ali.", "Just in the ring Ali.He is rated number 1 in most really good hall of fame heavyweight lists.Why because he beat more Hall of fame opponents than anyone including the two hardest punching heavyweight champions. He also beat 19 out of the top 100 heavyweights of all time!", "just in the ring I still go with ali, he fought the best ALL the time", "How many times have you seen the number one and number two champions of all time fight while they are still the number one and number two fighters in the world?\nRocky and Louis fought, but Joe was hardly the number one or two champion at the time, nor, in my opinion were Rocky and Joe the number one and two champions of all time.\nAsk yourself, did Ray Robinson ever fight the number two middleweight of all time while Ray was number one?\nMaybe someone can show me to be wrong about this, but off the top of my head, I don\u2019t think the number one and number two greatest of all time fought each other while they were still number one and number two. Duran/Leonard, nope. Leonard/Hearns, nope. Sanchez/Gomez, now that\u2019s a possibility but Gomez was not rated best or second best at featherweight when they fought and Gomez isn\u2019t the second greatest featherweight of all time.\nYou could make an argument that if Spence fought Crawford, we could have such a bout, but can you convince the pundits that Spence and Crawford are the best welterweights of all time? As super as each of these fighters are, I\u2019m not sure about that.\nBottom line, a twenty-two year old Clay fought who I believe to be the second greatest heavy of all time in Sonny Liston, while Ali was the best and Sonny was the second greatest heavy at the time. So true that Liston may have been sixty-seven years old when they fought and Liston may have had an injured shoulder, but on that day in 1964, I believe the greatest heavyweight of all time fought the second greatest heavyweight of all time, while both were still one and two.\nAnd I\u2019d ask you this; who other than Clay/Ali could have beaten Sonny Liston in the early sixties? And I\u2019m talking about any heavyweight champion before or since. Liston would have destroyed them all. From Joe Louis to Tyson Fury and everyone in between. The only two heavies I\u2019d give a chance against Liston of the late fifties, early sixties were Larry Holmes and Lennox Lewis and we know Lennox could be put to sleep. This was unheard of-any champion, especially a brand-new one who had just won the title had 1 calender year to fight the #1 contender in a mandatory defense under WBA / WBC rules. So Spinks should have had until February 1979 to face Norton. Ali and his handlers were stunned, and were desperate for Ali to regain the title. Spinks, who was paid a paltry $170,000 for the first fight-was offered 3.75 million to give Ali a rematch. Spinks accepted, of course.
