Except none race spec tyres, for PR purposes.\nThere are currently 4 engine suppliers, if you are one of those, you can build extra test engines, if you aren\u2019t, they are going to know your engine has one more hours than they know about.\nAll that said, there isn\u2019t much that can stop the various teams from building a car that looks very much like a F1 car, using an engine very much like an F1 engine, using tyres very much like F1 tyres.", "No, not any more and this has been the way for several years now. Instead there is a formal pre-season session at one of the circuits. Any of the teams can attend and there\u2019s no limit to how many laps they can do and they don\u2019t have to attend at all if they don\u2019t want to. For the 2020 season the test days were cut by 25% and the teams were also not allowed to hide their cars in their garages or behind screen to prevent the opposition from seeing them.\nOnce the season is underway no further testing of physical cars is allowed, any modifications to the cars have to be \u201ctested\u201d in computer simulations until fitted to the car at the next race.", "No.\nTesting is very limited in F1. Back in the 90 when there where no restrictions, teams would have the drivers out a lot. Schumacher was known to drive around the Fiorano track, even on race weekends between free practice and qualifying to optimize the car further (He did that only in Monaco and Monza as he could take the Helicopter back and forth there but he would test whenever possible).\nBut all this is banned now. Teams can rent a track (or some stretch of road) for a total of two film/ promotion days where they have to use special tires and can\u2019t drive more than 100km. Other than that there is only the official testing. This was done to cut costs, as the big teams had basically a complete additional testing team plus there own track and so on what gave them a massive advantage over the teams that could not afford this. When people complain now how Mercedes is so much ahead and how there is such a large gap between the top teams and the midfield, we forget that in the 90s the midfield was often 2\u20134 labs behind and the gaps were so much larger. The only reason there where more race winners were reliability issues.", "Yes, they test the cars alot. NO SEC fan puts conference over their school; that\u2019s not accurate.\nBeyond that falsehood, they cheer the conference for the same reason that New England fans are so defensive about their team, and Yankees fans are so defensive about their\u2019s - because so many outsiders tend to put the conference down. It may have to do with our success, with so many national championships over the last 20 years, but people tend to think there is a bias towards the SEC; like the voters and pollsters play favorites with us.\nIt may also be a leftover remnant of the Civil War (the War of Northern Aggression! LOL). The Southern states have often been treated as a stepchild in this country. Seen as not as ambitions or intelligent. I know that\u2019s a thought of many moons ago, but remnants of that thought remain. But because we\u2019re all kind of lumped into this same \u201credneck\u201d, \u201cbackwoods\u201d thought, we kind of bond together more than other places. We are by nature kind folks. We don\u2019t wish bad on anyone. And we\u2019re not trying to keep anyone from having theirs as long as we get ours. Now, no one is cheering for their rivals explicitly. I\u2019m not cheering for Alabama or Florida anytime soon. But I will say this - it IS a positive for the teams you play to do well because it advances your own resume\u2019. For instance - this year, LSU was undefeated. That\u2019s good anytime, but remember a few years back UCF went undefeated as well. No one gave them as much credit because they played in a lesser conference. They only played 2 ranked teams in the regular season, and one in a bowl game. LSU beat 3 top 5 teams, 4 top 10 teams, and 6 top 15 teams (according to their end of season rankings. More were ranked when they played them, and some were ranked higher when they played). There was a benefit to Auburn and Alabama and Florida doing well this season. No one was actively cheering for them to win all the games they did, but every win each of those teams got made LSU\u2019s season that much more dominant.\nSo I get that you are never going to cheer for Michigan. But you DO want Michigan to do well, otherwise any win you have over them is less meaningful. I get the tradition of the rivalry always makes it important, but for rankings, for people to look at your program as dominant, you need your rivals to play well too.\nAnd what you\u2019re talking about is not necessarily about Michigan. It would be more about the Big10. When the season ends and your conference goes off to play other conferences in bowl games, I\u2019d like to think you want your conference to win. Novita Anasri", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "Who has the most golden gloves in boxing?", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": "698", "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "185": {"ans_list": ["Variety of factors in play for this question. What is your draft position? What players are you losing (net of any free agent signings)? Is quarterback a critical position of need?\nIf you are drafting after the top 10 spots or so, then you most likely are reaching to pick based solely on position, unless you are well sorted at the handful of positions that are typically the highest-valued in the draft - QB, Edge rusher, and LT. Teams that have met these needs coming into the draft can usually afford the luxury of taking a position player on the basis that, early enough in the draft, the best position players on the board are also among the best athletes. So taking a highly-regarded WR, DB or LB in the first half of the first round can be a good move.\nQuarterbacks are often the most limited resource, because typically a team either has an incumbent franchise QB that is not going anywhere (so spending high draft picks on a stud would be wasted), or picks late enough that they can\u2019t trust that the very small number of QBs that can be expected to start as rookies will still be available. So for instance, The Cincinnati Bengals in 2020 had both great need and the #1 overall pick, so if they didn\u2019t take Joe Burrow, it would have been a monumental waste of the perfect opportunity to sort out their QB situation for the foreseeable future. Now, it\u2019s always possible for a #1 pick to be a bust (I mean, look at Ryan Leaf going #2 overall and then just being a complete horror show with a laughably short career), but for a #1 overall pick to turn out to be a complete miss is pretty amazingly bad luck for a team, and if you\u2019re picking #1, you\u2019re already so bad that you can only go up from there. I mean, the Cleveland Browns picked #1 overall two years in a row in 2017 and 2018, but that translated into a pretty strong improvement in 2019. Unfortunately, the problem was that they hit that bit of bad luck in that Baker Mayfield turned out to not be a world-class NFL QB, even though he may have been arguably the best of that class.\nSo, lastly, it comes down to the change in composition of your team in the off-season. Sometimes you just have someone leave in free agency, or retire, and don\u2019t have a quality starter at that position, and you have two options - replace that player via free agency, or reach down for a player that doesn\u2019t rate that high of a pick, but isn\u2019t still going to be there in the next round. So you have someone like Cesar Ruiz being picked #24 by the Saints, even though they drafted a starting center last year, and Ruiz was pegged as an early-second-round talent. The pick is a bit strange on the face of it, because Ruiz doesn\u2019t appear to meet a crucial need and also doesn\u2019t seem to have been the best athlete when NO was on the clock. They seemingly were trapped in that no-man\u2019s-land between having a worthy player that fit one of their more pressing needs, and they must have felt that the better athletes available were at positions where they were already set, so there was no point in bringing in a guy in the first round that is just likely to be cut in camp because he\u2019s got no roster spot. Ruiz\u2019s up-side is that he may be able to play Guard, so he gives NO a prospect to replace an aging player in a year or two, who can also be a backup Center. Is that a good enough argument to justify that pick? Who knows. Maybe that guy will end up being an All Pro before his career is over.", "Not that I am an expert or anything like that, but in some cases I would have to say so. Look at Lamar Jackson, not the best passer for quarterbacks but probably the best pure athlete and look at what he has accomplished. Terrell Owens is another example of a great athlete, or even Bo Jackson. Now when you combine that athleticism with great ATTITUDE then you really have something. Some people are just better athletes and can adapt to situations on the field better than others.\nI think that is why the Eagles drafted Jalen Hurts in the second round even though fans questioned the pick. Obviously Jalen is a superior athlete, but the fans felt that the Eagles should have drafted to NEED instead of best athlete available. Can the team fit the best athlete available into the team concept is another issue that teams face. Jamal Adams of the Jets is an example of a superior athlete who the organization may have issues with. Do they fit into the team concept? Did Terrell Owens fit into the team concept? You may or may not agree whether he did or did not, but make no mistake he was a great receiver who the defense had problems with. And finally the maybe best example is Deion Sanders who is the greatest cornerback of all time (Primetime). He made teams he was on Super Bowl contenders just by his presence. Blazing speed and pure athleticism beyond the reach of mere mortals, he set the stage for drama when he touched the ball. He even played 2 sports like Bo Jackson.\nSo yes picking the best athlete does have it merits if you are able to harness that pure athleticism into the team concept as they blend in.", "This is a classic choice between the team winning as a profitable business or the team winning games/championships.\nIf you wish to win as a profitable business, you pick the best athlete available. Best doesn\u2019t always mean the best player. It may mean the most popular (i.e. Brian Bosworth). The idea is to sell tickets/jerseys and have a bankable commodity to sell/trade to other teams in the future. You currently see teams in the NFL eating up quarterbacks due to this strategy.\nIf you wish to win games/championships, you employ one of two strategies. You can pick a player which fits the teams current needs (like you need a linebacker, so you pick a linebacker). Some coaches also believe in picking the best player based on character and \u201cwinning spirit.\u201d The player may not be the best athlete or a needed position, but they show incredible tenacity, are loyal/coachable and don\u2019t have any \u201cdistractions\u201d in their personal lives.", "It is the strategy that most teams use and IMO the best. Especially when it's BPA at position of need.\nIt the best players available when a team is on the clock dont fit a teams needs, either immediate or within a 2 year window, that team should try to trade down and add picks.the NFL is riddled with injuries, and short contracts. Benson was caught 63 times in 13 years, although the accessibility that made her popular was also the cause of controversy.. She has been referred to as \"the people's fish\" and was voted by readers of Angler's Mail as Britain's Favorite Carp in 2005. Benson lived in the Kingfisher Lake at the Bluebell Lakes complex at Tansor just outside Oundle in Northamptonshire. She was one of approximately 150 carp in Bluebell Lakes, which are managed \"to provide the best environment for growth potential of the fish\". The other parts are when they have to talk on the microphone to talk about their opponents that they'll be wrestling for that night or for when they're wrestling them at a event that hasn't happened yet but will take place in the same month in the future (such as a pay per view). This should at least be a two-club difference, perhaps even three or four.\nGenerally, on such holes, wind plays a big role. Often you are hitting from a tee that is located on a cliff, down into a valley or a river bed or seaside. If you are hitting into a valley or a gorge, wind mostly flows in one particular direction. But seaside or on open ground, it can howl and gust rather unpredictably - you might be hitting your PW, and your partner might be hitting his 6i a few minutes later. Hard to get a feel for such holes unless you have played it a few times (and hit a few mulligans).\nThat's why the great Lee Trevino used to jokingly call such holes \u201cworld's shortest par-5\u201d."], "topic_list": ["Golf Courses", "Golf", "Measurements", "Sports"], "view_list": [39], "create_time": "Apr 26, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Steve Rosasco", "upvote_list": [0], "question_title": "How much should I club down on a 140 yard par 3 where the green is 100 feet lower than the tee box?", "respond_collected": 1, "no_of_view": "365", "name_list": ["Vivek Tulja"], "date_list": ["Apr 26, 2020"]}, "1142": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["error"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "", "no_of_follower": 0, "question_author": "", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "error", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": 0, "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "1018": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["error"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "", "no_of_follower": 0, "question_author": "", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "error", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": 0, "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "389": {"ans_list": ["At the highest level probably rugby players.\nThough it\u2019s important to differentiate between different field positions. With such a huge history the league has some amazing facts and events that not every fan is aware of. There are hundreds of interesting facts to share about teams and players, but for the list, we have picked the top 10 NBA facts you must know.\n1. NBA banned Air Jordans once\nIf you play basketball at any level, then most probably one of the best all-time basketball sneakers are on your wish list. Born in 1985 Air Jordans were a sensation but not without a patchy start. During those players were told to wear only shoes that matched their uniforms. Although most sneakers were white during that time, Jordan\u2019s came in red and black combinations that matched the uniform a Chicago Bull, a similarity that former NBA commissioner David Stern hated.\nMichael Jordan was fined $5000 by Stern for every game he played in those sneakers. However, Jordan never cared as the fine was paid by Nike on his behalf, a small price for what the brand gained.\n2. The tallest player and the shortest player in NBA history were on the same team once\nThe tallest player ever in NBA, Manute Bol (7\u2019 7\u201d) and the shortest one Muggy Bogues (5\u2019 3\u201d) both played for Washington Bullets in 1987-1988 season.\nWhile Bol was an amazing shot-blocker and rebounder, he remains an underrated three-point shooter in NBA history. Bogues, on the other hand, was famous for his steals and known for his amazing athletic performance. He was so small for the game that during one of the matches he went through the legs of a player.\n3. LeBron James is ambidextrous\nJanuary 3, 2020; Los Angeles, California, USA; Los Angeles Lakers forward LeBron James (23) controls the ball against the New Orleans Pelicans during the second half at Staples Center. Mandatory Credit: Gary A. Vasquez-USA TODAY Sports\nArguably one of the most dominant NBA players presently, LeBron James is always seen using his right hand for shooting but outside the court, he does pretty much everything with his left hand. He can be usually seen writing or eating with his left hand.\nSpeaking on the same James told, during his childhood he tried to imitate his idols Penny Hardaway and Michael Jordan which led him to shoot with his right hand because they did the same. This fact leaves us wondering what might happen if LeBron starts shooting with his left hand too!!\n4. Paul Pierce played every game in 2000-01 season even after getting stabbed 11 times\nJul 10, 2019; Los Angeles, CA, USA; Former basketball player Paul Pierce arrives on the red carpet at Microsoft Theatre. Mandatory Credit: Kirby Lee-USA TODAY Sports\nIn a late-night brawl at a club on the fateful night of 25 September 2000, Paul Pierce was stabbed 11 times when he tried to stop a fight in a club in Boston. He was stabbed in his neck, back and face, but was taken to hospital on time by his teammate Tony Battie. He has to undergo lung surgery.\nHowever, his injuries were not enough to keep the player with a concrete mind from playing. Remarkably, he was back on the court just 3 days after the surgery. He played 82 games in 2001-02 period for the Boston Celtics, crazy, isn\u2019t it! But his shows how dedicated Pierce was to the game and his team.\n5. Almost 60% of NBA players go broke after 5 years of retirement\nBased on a study by Sports Illustrated it was found that around 60% of NBA players got into financial troubles within 5 years post-retirement.\nBut the question comes to mind, how NBA players who earn millions go broke, that too in such a short span? The answer is obvious if you look at their lifestyle and spendthrift nature. Cars, shoes, houses and parties are a common part of their luxurious lifestyle along with poor money investments. It makes it easy to imagine how all that money vanishes.\nEvery NBA player can take a page from LeBron\u2019s book who is financially smart and knows the value of money. He has hired people to look after his business and finance.\n6. NBA has never witnessed a quintuple-double\nIf you follow the NBA, you know that double-doubles and triple-doubles are common, but what about quadruple-double?\nIn entire NBA history, only four players ever had a quadruple-double-Nate Thurmond (22 points, 14 rebounds, 13 assists, 12 blocks), David Robinson (34 points, 10 rebounds, 10 assists, 10 blocks), Alvin Robertson (20 points, 11 rebounds, 10 assists, 10 steals), and Hakeem olajuwon (18 points , 16 rebounds , 10 assists , 11 blocks).\nAs we mentioned the any of the NBA courts are still to witness a quintuple-double.\n7. Shaquille O\u2019Neal made only one three-point shot out of 22 attempts\nIt\u2019s hard to believe that a four-time NBA champion and 15-times NBA All-Star player who dominated all the aspects of the game will have such low score in three-point shooting. During his career, Shaq attempted 22 three-pointers but was able to convert only one.\n8. The shortest player in NBA history blocked 39 shots\nIf you bet on NBA games, then most probably you will never pick the shortest player on the court as your favorite. But NBA odds aside, the shortest player in NBA history, Tyrone \u201cMuggsy\u201d Bogues who stood only 5\u2019 3\u201d fought his way into the NBA. Not only he made it to the prestigious league but blocked 39 shots throughout his career. Now, that\u2019s extraordinary!\n9. Kobe Bryant\u2019s parents co-signed his first NBA contract\nNov 17, 2019; Los Angeles, CA, USA; Former Lakers player Kobe Bryant acknowledges the crowd during the second quarter against the Atlanta Hawks at Staples Center. Mandatory Credit: Kelvin Kuo-USA TODAY Sports\nFor the 1996 NBA draft, Kobe Bryant was the 13th pick, selected by the Charlotte Hornets. However, he was immediately traded by the team to Los Angeles Lakes and as most of us know rest is history. But what some of you might now know is that Bryant was under 18 when he was drafted. Boxing would win. Hands down, and probably faster than any of the others could manage it. Second place would be modern street MMA, then probably jujitsu. It suffers from a fatal flaw in the streets, and that's because of its emphasis on groundwork. DO NOT GO TO GROUND IN A STREET FIGHT. EVER! It has diverse methods, fighters can usually take punishment, and it's relatively easy to find a school. However, it takes a \u201cwide river\u201d approach, spreading itself a bit thin amongst lots of techniques, and it too relies a bit heavily on wrestling and groundwork.\nWhy boxing? I hear you ask. Those jokers don't even kick. They don't throw. They don't tap others out. This is all true. There are three major factors in their favor.\nBoxers. Are. Fast. Mindbendingly so. The slowest amateur boxer's hands are a blur compared to the measured strikes of other arts. This is because they train with them exclusively. They train to hit the hard target that is the head. They train to strike flurries up and down the upper body which are insanely difficult to defend.\nBoxers can take a beating. The boxer with the worst glass chin in the world can take hits that would crumple a karateka or jujitsu player. They train to do this. Their upper body is harder than a rock. just after it has bounced (when the ball is, say, no more than a foot off the ground). Regarded as a \u201cbad\u201d ball, it gives the batsman a run-scoring opportunity with little chance of giving a catch.", "In tennis, the half-volley is the shot you hit when the ball lands in the court right in front of you and you hit it from low on the court as the ball rises, usually while in the forecourt while trying to get to net.\nTypically, when your opponent sees you trying to hit this shot, they will advance, hoping for you to hit a shot upwards where they might volley it off for a winner. Some people have very long or very short arms for their body size. But, in general, a person\u2019s armspan \u2014 from tip of middle finger to tip of middle finger \u2014 is equal to their height. I had a college friend who could not stand up straight. She said her doctors measured her height by measuring the distance from hand-tip to hand-tip.\nQ: What is the average wingspan/reach of someone who is 6\u2019?", "The average wingspan of a 6\u00b40 man is equal to their height.\nThe standing reach would be 8\u00b40"], "topic_list": ["Wingspan", "Humans", "Height", "Sports", "Human Body"], "view_list": [37, 8], "create_time": "Apr 27, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Anonymous", "upvote_list": [1, 0], "question_title": "What is the average wingspan/reach of someone who is 6\u2019?", "respond_collected": 2, "no_of_view": "827", "name_list": ["Linda Russell", "Angelo Bowens"], "date_list": ["Apr 27, 2020", "Apr 27, 2020"]}, "1558": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["error"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "", "no_of_follower": 0, "question_author": "", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "error", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": 0, "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "714": {"ans_list": ["In stroke (also called medal) play, it\u2019s an etiquette infraction only, no penalty. Players are encouraged these days to hit it when ready, AKA \u201cready golf\u201d to save time and keep groups moving. Moving along the fairway, it\u2019s best to let the player who\u2019s ball is reached first to play his shot, then everyone move forward, for safety\u2019s sake.\nAround the green, the player furthest away is supposed to putt or chip first, but there\u2019s no problem with \u201cfinishing\u201d with a second stroke if it\u2019s going to get you done with your work around the green. Again, faster play. Tapping in a birdie before the other guys putt and chip is okay, too, since you\u2019re up there marking your ball anyway. Just knock it in, if your stance isn\u2019t going to leave footprints in somebody\u2019s line. No penalty.\nMatch play is a different matter. Hit your shot out of turn and the opposing player has the option of making you take it (if it\u2019s a bad shot) or hitting over again (if it\u2019s a good shot). That\u2019s the \u201cpenalty.\u201d No strokes added or loss of hole.\nGroups playing combo medal and match play, like a Nassau, default to the match play rules. Hit out of turn, especially on the tee, and you might have to do it over.\nI actually pulled this on an opponent on the 18th tee in an individual match. All square, it\u2019s my honor and he hits his drive first. It\u2019s a tough driving hole, miss the fairway and par is difficult. He hits a good one. I say, \u201cNice shot! It wasn\u2019t your turn, though.\u201d\nHe looks at me like he can\u2019t believe it. The other guy with us is griping, \u201cYou can\u2019t be serious.\u201d\n\u201cMatch play, baby,\u201d I tell them, step up to the tee and pipe it. Opponent has to hit his over again. You already know how this story turns out.", "Who cares?", "In stroke play, no penalty. In match play, your opponent may require you to play your shot over."], "topic_list": ["Golf Courses", "Golf", "Sports"], "view_list": [105, 9, 13], "create_time": "Apr 22, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Mohammed Saiful Alam Siddiquee (\u092e\u0941\u0939\u092e\u094d\u092e\u0926 \u0938\u0948\u092b\u0941\u0932 \u0906\u0932\u092e \u0938\u093f\u0926\u094d\u0926\u0940\u0915\u0940)", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0], "question_title": "What is the penalty for playing out of turn in golf?", "respond_collected": 3, "no_of_view": "1,863", "name_list": ["Don Stuart", "Toma Mundo", "Brad Jones"], "date_list": ["Apr 22, 2020", "Apr 22, 2020", "Apr 22, 2020"]}, "485": {"ans_list": ["NO, Foreman was the harderst puncher of all time, Earnie Shavers was next.", "According to George Foreman, Liston hit far harder than he did. According to the two fighters cleanly hit by both, Chuck Wepner and \u201cScrap Iron\u201d Johnson, it was Liston, and according to the only trainer who trained them both, it was Liston.\nLet us examine five factors:\nwhat did fighters who faced both say?\nwhat did trainers who trained both say?\nwhat do their records tell us? And not just the KO percentage which fanboys who don\u2019t know boxing think is the be all and end all - no, look at who they fought, and even more importantly the style they used, because while Foreman was a pure slugger, Sonny was a master boxer, and a boxer-puncher\nwhat did opponents of both say about their power, not the opponents they had in common, but their other opponents, what was their reaction to Sonny and George?\nwhat feats of power did either do which tells us which was the more powerful?\nAt the end, all five factors will tell you Sonny Liston hit harder.\nCREDIT PICTURE MID SOUTH BOXING\nSo on to factor one, what the men who fought them both said!\nThe guys who fought them both said Liston was far more powerful\nThe only three men who fought them both were Scrap Iron Johnson, Ali and Chuck Wepner. Ali said Foreman hit him harder than anyone else - but added that he was able to keep Sonny from landing a solid shot on him.\nAli said in Ali: A Life \u201cThe thing with George, I had to let him hit me, the thing with Sonny, I had to make sure he didn\u2019t hit me!\u201d\nChuck Wepner said \"Sonny made George [Foreman] look like Mr. Friendly!\" He went on to say that being hit by Foreman was like being hit by an unbelievably strong man, but being hit by Sonny was like being hit by a baseball bat.\nGeorge \u201cScrap Iron\u201d Johnson was an expert on the Golden Age sluggers, having fought Jerry Quarry, (twice!) Eddie Machen, Joe Frazier, Sonny Liston, George Foreman, Duane Bobick and Ron Lyle!\nJohnson was stopped by Liston after he was beaten into helplessness in the 7th round. Scrap Iron lost to Foreman after a cut in the 7th round, and otherwise was fine.\nSonny knocked the tough as old shoe leather Scrap Iron down, and George didn\u2019t.\nSonny was at least 41 that night, George was 21, and Sonny was clearly more powerful. Scrap Iron, who had fought George Foreman, Sonny Liston, and Joe Frazier, said of the three Sonny was the hardest hitter. (though his manager picked Joe Frazier!)\nThe only trainer who worked with them both said Liston was more powerful and hit harder\nTrainer Johnny Tocco, who worked with Foreman, Tyson and Sonny Liston, said of the three, Liston hit the hardest, and was the strongest.\nSo did Emmanuel Steward, who said of Liston, \"he was unbelievably strong, and his punching like a wrecking machine.\"\nKO Numbers are not the end all be all of power discussions, unless you know nothing of boxing, Sonny fought and beat far better competition from day one of his career, and his style was not that of a pure slugger as George\u2019s was\nFanboys chanting statistics, saying \u201cnumbers don\u2019t lie,\u201d forget that numbers do lie, as the old saying Mark Twain loved so much says: \"There are three kinds of lies: lies, damned lies, and statistics.\"\nPeople cite KO numbers like they are the end all be all of power discussions - they are not. A good example is Vitali Klitschko, whose KO percentage is second only to Marciano\u2019s. (87% to Rocky\u2019s 88%) That is 10 points higher than his brother Wlad Klitschko. But Chris Byrd, who fought them both, said flatly that Wlad hit far harder - yet Wlad\u2019s KO percentage was 10 points lower!\nHow can that be, fanboys ask?\nBecause, according to Manny Steward, Wlad had to guard his chin, and thus was not free to tee off on people the way his brother was - Vitali, with an iron chin, could just beat people up without having to worry about them beating him up the way Wlad did.\nBut there is more:\nWhy do you think George, with a better record on paper, 76\u20135 to Sonny\u2019s 50\u20134, is ranked far behind him in the all time rankings? For those who don\u2019t know, Sonny is ranked #4 by Boxrec, and George is #19.\nSonny fought better competition than George, right from the beginning.\nSonny\u2019s first 10 opponents had a combined record of 109\u201351, and in his 6th fight he was thrown in with all time great, #121 of all time, Johnny Summerlin, who. (Sonny beat him, and when a rematch was scheduled, because Johnny\u2019s manager could not believe it, Sonny beat him again!)\nSonny had been fighting 9 months, and had six fights, when he was thrown in with 18\u20131 Johnny Summerlin, who had been fighting for nearly 5 years!\nYet Sonny beat him on points, because as Summerlin later said, after Sonny\u2019s first jab hit him, he ran for his life.\nNow look at George\u2019s first 10 opponents. They were a combined 87\u201371, and the first time George faced a fighter who ranks in the top 200 was #151 Geraldo Peralta in his 27th fight, plus George having fought in the Olympics where he won Gold!\nGeorge was fed a magnificent diet of tomato cans.\nWe run into this trouble often with fanboys screaming how great Deontay Wilder is as a puncher. In Joe Louis, his trainer, the great Jack Blackburn, one of the 5 greatest trainers in history was quoted saying he could take a low level journeyman and make him 20\u20130, and have him knocking out everyone - until, Jack said, sooner or later he would have to fight someone who could fight.\nAnd it was not just in the beginning, but all through their careers, that Sonny fought tougher competition.\nSonny fought and beat a lot tougher opponents than George, as an all time comparison shows\nSonny Liston faced all 7 time top 100 fighters:\n#2 Muhammad Ali\n#15 Floyd Patterson\n#22 Cleveland Williams\n#28 Eddie Machen\n#36 Zora Folley\n#59 Nino Valdes\n#92 Leotis Martin\nSonny faced 7 top 100 fighters, beating 5 of them, or 72%.\nGeorge faced 5 top 100 opponents:\n#2 Muhammad Ali\n#11 Evander Holyfield\n#13 Joe Frazier\n#34 Ken Norton\n#61 Michael Moorer\nGeorge faced 5 top 100 fighters, losing to 2 for a 60% win rate against top competition.\nSonny was a rare creature, a boxer-puncher of incredible power who did not head hunt\nSonny was that rarest of creatures, a slugger with all time power who could actually box.\nSonny was a vastly underrated boxer, with excellent fundamentals, a poleax jab, and knockout power in either hand. During the 50's, in his prime, he was avoided like the plague, Joe Louis said he was glad he never had to face Sonny.\nSonny Liston was a truly outstanding technical boxer. Despite his awesome strength and power, \u201che took his time to set his opponents up, to gauge their skills and reaction time, before finishing them,\u201d said Angelo Dundee.\nAccording to Muhammad Ali, the second greatest heavyweight of all time, was Sonny Liston. Ali was a great admirer of Liston\u2019s talent, saying that Liston could do just about everything except dance. (and Ali said besides himself, there\u2019d never really been a dancing heavyweight). Ali said Liston had a tremendous jab, could punch with either hand, was smart in the ring and was as strong as any heavyweight he\u2019d ever seen.\nGeorge Foreman said \"Sonny Liston could whip any other heavyweight in history except for Ali.\"\nJoe Frazier, when asked if Larry Holmes had the best jab he had ever seen, said \"nope. Ali's was better.\" Then he paused and said \"and Sonny Liston, of course.\"\nA good barometer of how good Sonny Liston was comes with his twice destroying a very good heavyweight champion, Floyd Patterson, in the first round each time - when he was much older than Patterson!\nNor was it a freak accident when Liston wiped the floor up with Patterson - Boxing writer and historian Bobby Franklin said, while marveling at Liston's skills at such an advanced age, \"it is interesting to note that while the fights were blow outs, Liston did not come out swinging wildly. He took Floyd apart methodically, setting his man up with left jabs and solid body shots. Sonny showed fast hands, using an accurate left jab, along with hooks and uppercuts. He had a definite game plan and executed it perfectly. If they fought a hundred times during that period the result would have been the same.\"\nThe fights which best exemplify Liston\u2019s strengths are his two short contests with Cleveland Williams. Monte Cox said it best: \u201cListon used beautiful head movement and what may be the division\u2019s greatest ever jab to avoid most of Williams\u2019 punches and to keep him off balance. Williams does occasionally land with extraordinarily powerful shots, but Sonny shakes each one off. In their combined five rounds of boxing over the course of their two fights, Liston is only shaken briefly once, and never in danger of being dropped. The most astounding thing about his approach is that he is equally comfortable coming forward or retreating\u2014which he does whenever he feels pressured. This runs entirely contrary to the perceived wisdom about Sonny Liston. Although he was a finisher of comparable stature to Dempsey, Louis, Marciano, and Frazier, he was the only member of this shark-like group who was a boxing conservative.\u201d\nBoxing historians consider Charles (\"Sonny\") Liston a great heavyweight. Indeed, Ring magazine ranks Liston as the seventh greatest heavyweight of all time, and boxing writer Herb Goldman ranked him second. Boxing writer Springs Toedo, in his book, The Gods of War, lays out a powerful case that Liston, when at his peak in the late 1950s and early 1960s, could be favored to beat just about every heavyweight champion in the modern era with the possible exception of a young and prime Muhammad Ali.\nBoxrec\u2019s computer, factoring in strength of competition, lists Sonny as #4 all time great, even though he did not start boxing until his mid 20\u2019s, and competed till at least 42, and he was probably far older!\nSonny ended his career 50-4, with 39 KO's, and all his defeats, except one, which he supposedly threw for the Mob, occurred when he was old! Indeed, his last defeat probably occurred when he was over 42 years old! At his peak, boxing historians believe he would have been a match for any heavyweight ever, with again, the possible exception of Ali.\nSonny won 15 of 16 matches after his defeats by Ali, and the only one he lost he was handily winning until getting caught with a lucky punch, when he was at least 42.\nGeorge was a seek and destroy knockout artist in his prime\nYoung Foreman was the most feared heavyweight in history other than Sonny Liston, and Prime Tyson. He had a thunderous, accurate jab, incredible power in both hands, greater strength than practically anyone else who ever set foot in the ring, (with the possible exception of Sonny Liston and Jim Jeffries), he cut the ring off well - had he not fallen to Ali in Zaire, he would have terrorized the heavyweights for a decade.\nPrime George Foreman had Power, (with a capital P) and in his prime, was an astonishingly athletic and fast fighter who cut off the ring as well as anyone since Joe Louis, (who said Foreman cut the ring off better than him, and better than any other fighter, ever). All time greats such as Jack Dempsey and Joe Louis both commented that Foreman may have been the strongest heavyweight hitter that they had ever seen, certainly the strongest since Sonny Liston.\nAngelo Dundee noted this about Foreman before the fight with Frazier for the title: \"He's got a jab like I've never seen on a heavyweight since Sonny Liston. He has a strong left hand. I mean strong. He can stop a man in his tracks.\"\nGeorge Foreman at his awesome 1973 best may have been, except for Liston, the most powerful heavyweight champion ever. At 6\u20193 \u00bd\u201d and 220 pounds, with an 79\u201d reach he was the best of the \u201csuper-heavyweights.\u201d\nAfter his destruction of Ken Norton, he was 40-0 with 37 knockouts, for a knockout percentage of 92.50. In his career Foreman had 15 first round knockouts and 18 second round knockouts. That's 33 knockouts inside of the first 2 rounds! He had 46 knockouts that were 3 rounds or less, which is more than any other heavyweight champion. George Foreman\u2019s incredible two round destruction of Joe Frazier was the most one-sided beating ever delivered upon an undefeated heavyweight champion.\nIn his prime, George brought to the ring not only exceptional raw power and confidence but also a frightening arsenal of various punches. His uppercuts could lift a man off their feet, his hooks were paralyzing, his strong left jab was true, his right hand, although not often thrown straight was a decapitating blow thrown short or long. He used his massive arms to block punches and could parry punches with his rear hand. He would sometimes slap opponent\u2019s guards down with his hands and then batter them with massive power shots to the head and body. The Foreman of 73-74 also may have been the best ever at cutting down and off the ring on his opponents.\nBut Dick Sadler who trained Foreman, had stopped even trying to hone the boxing skills Sonny Liston had installed him - when George would ask what to do in the gym, Sadler would just tell him to go beat the heavy bag, and when asked about it, said nobody could stand up to George.\nUnlike Sonny, who was a true boxing master, George in his first career was a pure knockout artist - and that was all Sadler trained him to be. Sonny, on the other hand, concentrated on his boxing skills, and let knockouts come if they did.\nSonny was far stronger than George, (who is pretty damn strong!)\nWhat did their opponent\u2019s or other fighters say?\nGeorge was simply described as incredibly strong, and his punches extraordinary.\nBut Sonny was described as some sort of superman.\nRocky Marciano said of Liston, \"he isn't faking his toughness, and his strength is just something you got to see, and that jab, he can knock a man out with the jab!\"\nWayne Bethea, a tough journeyman who had never been off his feet, said after being stopped by Liston \"he must have hit me with a horseshoe in his glove!\"\nZora Folley, then #1 contender for the heavyweight title, said when Liston hit him \u201cthe lights went out, when I woke up, I asked Sonny, what happened, and he said \u2018I hit you.\u2019\u201d\nFoley said later, \"I was lucky, Sonny didn't dislike me, so he just beat me up a little.\" Foley went on, \"ain't a man that walks this earth stronger than Sonny Liston.\"\nNino Valdes, as he lay dying from cancer, drugged heavily with morphine, was asked by his family if it hurt, and said \"not as bad as getting hit by Sonny Liston!\"\nCleveland Williams, after almost dying from a police shooting, was asked how bad it hurt, and said \u201cnot as bad as fighting Sonny Liston!\u201d Williams went on to say \"no human being hits as hard as Sonny Liston.\"\nWhen Sonny was getting ready to get out of prison in 1950, in order to showcase his potential - he had never had an amateur or pro fight - the prison athletic director, Father Stephens, arranged to bring in a rising St. Louis heavyweight named named Thurman Wilson, who was 5-2-1 as a pro, to showcase Liston's potential. Wilson expected no trouble with a man who had never had a sanctioned fight, amateur, or professional. The story is that after two rounds, (the exhibition was scheduled for 4) Wilson quit saying \"Better get me out of this ring,\" exclaimed Wilson, \"he is going to kill me.\"\nSir Henry Cooper, the European and British heavyweight Champion who twice fought Ali, and had a who's who of opponents in the 50's and 60's, had one name glaringly missing from his resume: Sonny Liston. When asked why, Sir Henry\u2019s manager said \"I don't even want to see him walking down the street, let alone in a gym!\"\nGeorge was strong enough to pull a car up a hill - but not as strong as Sonny LIston\nGeorge Foreman, who sparred with Sonny in 1968 - when Sonny was at least in his late 30's or 40's - said Sonny was the only man to force him backwards by sheer brute strength.\nA good example of Sonny's sheer strength was an exercise he devised in training camp of loading an industrial sized wheelbarrow full of rocks, and wheeling it up and down a hill. Foreman, 19, and training with \"the old man,\" could only carry one wheelbarrow for every 3 for Sonny. \"His strength,\" said Foreman, \"you just can't believe how strong he was!\" (Foreman later took Sonny's idea, and pulled a car up and down a hill to train!)\nSonny was born into a family that couldn't afford for him to go to school, and when the family mule died, Sonny's father hitched his 9 year old son to the plow and made him the mule.\nSonny, a child, pulled a plow all day that a mule struggled to pull.\n\u201cSonny once started a fight with a cop, beat the cop senseless, snatched his gun, picked him up and dumped him in an alley,\" recounts Jonathan Eig in \"Muhammad Ali: A Life.\"\nEig recounted: \"[Sonny] then walked away smiling, wearing the cop's hat.\"\nArrested 19 times, in prison twice, Sonny once took a gun away from a police officer who was harassing him, beat the officer and broke his knee. On another occasion when he was again being harassed, an enraged Sonny took the officer, literally picked him up over his head, and hurled him into a trash bin.\nGeorge hit hard, but some of Sonny\u2019s feats are literally legendary\nGeorge did knock out people - he even lifted Joe Frazier off the ground and hurled him backwards with his blows!\nBut Sonny Liston did a lot more than that.\nSonny Liston knocking out Wayne Bethea in 1958 in 69 seconds of the first round. Liston dropped Bethea for the first time in his career, knocking out 7 teeth, with 9 more broken! 16 teeth knocked out or broken with one punch!\nBethea was never the same again.\nNor was that the only time Sonny hit men with unbelievable power that eclipse's anything anyone else has done - in the mid 60's, Sonny sparred with Ray Shoeninger in Denver, and he hit him with a jab so hard, the stitching in Ray's protective headgear literally tore and the headgear came apart with the blow, which getting through, knocked out three teeth!\nSonny's first pro fight lasted 33 seconds: Liston leveled Don Smith with his first punch - which was a left jab, and Smith was out for 3 minutes!\nFrom February of 1959, to his march to the title, Sonny decimated the top ten ratings, knocking out 8 out of the top 10 contenders. Only Ingemar Johansson and Henry Cooper, of those fighters rated in the top ten during Liston\u2019s prime years, escaped beatings by him - and they declined to fight him. Only Eddie Machen survived all 12 rounds, when asked how, he said \u201cI ran for my life.\u201d\nHis opponents during this period had a combined record of four hundred nineteen wins with only ninety-nine losses. (Bear in mind that thirteen of those losses came to Liston himself.)\nNO other fighter in history has destroyed the top 10 the way Sonny did.\nIngemar Johannson later co-promoted Sonny\u2019s fights in Sweden, after Ali 2. When asked why he never fought Sonny himself, Johannson quipped that he had no intention of ever doing so, but he would cheerfully promote other men getting beat up by Sonny.\nThurman Wilson, who was 5-2-1 as a pro, and who was brought in to help Sonny show his ability, the pro who quit in the 2nd round because of the terrible beating he was taking?\nWilson never fought again after the beating by Liston.\nFloyd Patterson never, at any point, believed he actually could win against Liston.\nPatterson was so convinced he would lose he brought a disguise to the arena \"so I could get out of the place without anyone seeing how humiliated I was going to be.\"\nIn fact, Patterson wore a fake beard and mustache while fleeing in shame from Comiskey Park and Chicago after his crushing defeat.\nBoxing writer Charles Farrell wrote that \"I asked Floyd (Patterson) who the hardest puncher he\u2019d ever faced was. I thought I knew the answer. But Patterson surprised me. \u201cIngemar Johansson.\u201d (Patterson said)\n\u201cBut Floyd,\" i said, \"you fought Liston twice. Ingemar Johansson?\u201d Floyd smiled sadly, according to Farrell. \u201cOh, but when I fought Ingemar, I thought I was going to win. And of course against Sonny\u2026\u201d\nThe boxing establishment deliberately tried to downplay how great Liston was\nA despicable and deliberate effort by the boxing establishment has caused Sonny name to fade into obscurity. People have forgotten how feared Liston was. By 1964 he was considered unbeatable. He had lost once in 36 bouts \u2013 and that defeat in 1954, during which he suffered a broken jaw but ploughed on, merely added to his reputation. One contemporary profile said he was \"surprisingly fast, remarkably quick\" and noted his punishing jab while the former heavyweight champion Joe Louis admitted, \"I'm glad he wasn't around when I was fighting.\"\nAfter Ali\u2019s first victory over Sonny, a Boxing Illustrated editorial remarked: \"Nobody wants to be reminded of Sonny Liston. The idea is to forget him.\" And shamefully, forget him people did.\nThat is a factor today, when folks who don\u2019t study boxing claim Foreman could hit harder. He couldn\u2019t.\nCleveland Williams, the Big Cat, said \"there's tough guys in this business, and there's mean guys in this business, and then there's Sonny Liston.\"\nPerhaps a profile of the then world champion in the 1964 Boxing\nYearbook captured the awesome power and tortured soul of Sonny Liston best by saying: \"For Sonny Liston, it was easy being a superman. It was being a man that was often difficult.\"\nCREDIT TO:\nAll rankings and statistics to Boxrec\nCREDIT FOR ALL STORIES RELATED AND QUOTES CITED:\nAli: A Life by Jonathan Eig\nBy George by George Foreman\nCox\u2019s Corner and Monte Cox\nThe Gods of War by Springs Toedo\nFloyd Patterson: The Fighting Life of Boxing's Invisible Champion by W. I think liston had better jab but fireman better right", "Respectfully no, Foreman has much more fights than Liston and still has a much more higher knockout ratio than Liston. You want evidence?? don\u2019t just look at their highlights, go look at their stats, numbers don\u2019t lie!!\nForeman at the end of his career had 76 wins, 68 of them were by TKO or KO stoppage, and if you're good at math, that\u2019s a 89% knockout ratio wins, and to be more specific 27 of his 68 stoppages were pure knockouts.\nListon at the end of his career had 50 wins, 39 of them were by TKO or KO stoppages, that\u2019s a 78% knockout ratio wins, 13 of his 39 stoppages were pure knockouts.\nThat alone should tells you who\u2019s the harder puncher here. So I would and George Liston!", "Liston had more one punch KO`s, Foreman usually needed to land several punches to stop an opponent, Liston knocked Floyd Patterson out in 1 round with his fearsome left hook in two differrenet back to back fights and he knocked Cleveland Williams out in two fights with that same lethal punch, Liston`s hook was more powerful than any single Foreman punch.", "I think the only way to answer this would be to ask the guys who fought them both. Has Ali ever said who was the harder puncher? The caveat to him would be that I don\u2019t know that Liston really hit him as hard as he could. I think Foreman was a sparring partner for Liston, so he would probably know as well. I would look around for common opponents and see what they said.\nI will say though, and this is no knock on Foreman, but Liston was much more skilled than Foreman with his fundamentals. George used to load up a lot and he had a tendency to swing wide. Liston did a little too, especially when he was trying to finish a guy off. I think Sonny had better technique when it came to throwing a straight, hard shot. But I haven\u2019t watched either one of them in a while, so I\u2019m just going by memory.\nI haven\u2019t read the other answers yet, but my other \u201cgo to\u201d would be whatever Howard Schwartz says.", "When Foreman first started out as a professional fighter he sparred and trained with Sonny Liston. This would have been a 20 year old Foreman and a 45 to 48 year old Liston. Foreman has said that Sonny Liston was the only man strong enough to force him backward in the ring. Sonny Liston use to train, in part, by filling a wheelbarrow full of stones and pushing the wheelbarrow up and down a hill, Foreman said he couldn't keep up with Liston. When they sparred Foreman said Liston hit him harder than anyone had in his life. Foreman didnt say that at age 20, he said that after he had been in the ring with Ali, and Frazier, and Norton, and Ron Lyle.\nForeman has said that Liston was stronger than him and I think we can draw from that he believes Sonny Liston hit harder.", "You can look at the stats that might tell you one thing. You may listen to those who were in the ring with both of them and you will get different answers, but I base my take on one fight and I\u2019ve mentioned this before.\nBig George knocked down Joe Frazier six times and Joe got up each time. George says Joe would still be getting up if the ref didn\u2019t stop it. In my wildest imagination, I don\u2019t see Frazier getting up more than once if he was hit like that by Liston. I\u2019m sorry, I don\u2019t care if Joe had his chin transplanted with granite, nobody gets hit like that by Sonny Liston and gets up more than once.\nAli, who says Foreman was a bigger hitter than Sonny, used the rope a dope against Foreman and got clobbered more than once as George wailed away with every fucking thing he had. I don\u2019t know that Liston ever hit Ali big time in the aggregate seven rounds they fought. Hell, I think Sonny made damn sure he didn\u2019t hit Ali at all in the second \u201cfight.\u201d Regardless, no way Ali was ever hit with Sonny\u2019s best while Ali was hit with everything Foreman had.\nAli repeatedly asked Foreman throughout the fight, \u201cIs that all you got, George?\u201d And it was all George had. Ali never asked Liston that question. Why? Because Ali wouldn\u2019t let Sonny close enough to ask that question and Sonny never caught Ali like Foreman did. And I promise, if Sonny ever caught Ali like Foreman did, Ali wouldn\u2019t be asking Sonny any such question.\nSonny puts Frazier to sleep with one or two shots. Foreman couldn\u2019t come close to doing that. And if you want to go purely by stats, you would probably come up with Earnie Shavers as the biggest puncher ever. While Earnie was indeed a huge puncher, I don\u2019t think statistics always give you the correct answer.", ".\nnot harder. but more precise ,Foreman in younger years bludgeoned his punches, tightened up his delivery in his later years comeback", "Who knows?", "Chuck Wepner fought both of them, less than a year apart, and he repeatedly said Liston was the hardest puncher he ever fought.\n\u201cHe was the hardest puncher that I ever fought,\u201d said Wepner, \u201cIt was like getting hit with a baseball bat.\u201d\nSource: Requiem for a Heavyweight: The Mysterious Death of Sonny Liston | FIGHTLAND\nBut who knows. They were both terrifying punchers. Watching clips of Liston recently, what stood out is how hard his left jab was. It\u2019s a punch that\u2019s usually used to keep some distance, to distract and set up strong punches\u2014it\u2019ll sting someone and irritate them, but it won\u2019t hurt them on its own. Unless it\u2019s Sonny Liston\u2019s\u2014his opponents would get hit with a jab and look like they just got hit with a cannonball. He was knocking people down with jabs.\nI wouldn\u2019t be shocked if Foreman\u2019s right hand or hooks or uppercuts were as strong as (or maybe stronger than) Liston\u2019s\u2014but his left jab probably wasn\u2019t as strong. And since the left jab is usually the most common punch thrown and taken (my guess would be 3\u20134 X more than all the other punches), going a few rounds with Liston must have been truly awful.\nI know many people think Clay/Ali won because the fights were fixed, but I think Clay/Ali had the perfect approach to beating Liston\u2014don\u2019t box him, just be so light on your feet that you can dance around the edges of the ring with such swiftness that he can\u2019t hit you. Muhammad Ali may have been the only heavyweight that had the endurance and agility to keep that up all through a match. In the second match, his agility, speed, and precision seems to have been enough to get in a great right hook when Liston wasn\u2019t expecting it.", "Well, Foreman admitted that Sonny Liston was the only man, ever, to make him back up, and it was during sparring and at a point in which not only was Liston past his prime, but also likely close to 50 years old\u2026\nUltimately, any answer, I believe, will be subjective, even though backed by objective facts. Here\u2019s one fact: they are both all-time tremendous punchers and could have knocked out any man in boxing history. They are among the hardest punchers the sports has ever seen.\nNow, comparing the records of both, Foreman gets the upper hand. More knockouts (68 vs. Liston\u2019s 39) and, especially, a better KO ratio (84% vs. Liston\u2019s 72%); Foreman may have fought, and knocked out, generally speaking, more easier opponentes than Sonny (the first 20, or so, fights after his comeback were against very poor competition, for example), but the numbers give him the edge here, and the fact his that he was able to put down legends like Joe Frazier, Ken Norton, Ron Lyle and to TKO George Chuvalo (the guy with the greatest chin in the HW history).\nChuck Wepner and Muhammad Ali fought both men, and they would disagree on which was the hardest puncher. Ali states that \u201cof all the men I have fought, Foreman was the most powerful\u201d, while Liston was the \u201cscariest\u201d (in The Soul of a Butterfly); Wepner, on the other hand, said that nobody hit him harder than Sonny Liston, not even Foreman.\nThe Ring Magazine considers Foreman the 9th greatest puncher of all time - Liston is 15th on their list. Although they were both sluggers, depending on the strenght of their punches to win the fight, they\u2019re offensive style was different: Liston was more mobile and had a more refined punch, while Foreman, usually, would hinge on brute force. The first seven numbered balls are a solid color while the last seven numbered balls are striped and the 8-ball in the middle of the two halves is solid black. The first ball in the first seven numbered balls is yellow as is the first ball in the second seven numbered balls, that is the 9 ball. This color scheme is repeated as you can see the second in each half is royal blue, the third, bright red, the forth is purple, fifth orange, sixth, green, seventh burgundy, and the eight ball the one in the middle between the first and second halves of the rack is Black.\nAn exception to this is the newly designed pool balls made for TV, with a pink 4 ball and a pink 12 ball and a spotted cue ball. Why pink, because there is no discernable difference between the old royal blue 2-ball and the old purple 4-ball in previous sets as seen on television. So they made the 4 and 12 balls pink so, in a televised match of a game of 9-ball, a viewer could see better which ball the player was shooting shape for in their next shot. Before it was quite confusing until after the shot was made.\nAnd while they were making it better for the TV viewer, they put spots on the cue ball so the viewer could tell what sort of spin was placed on the cue ball. "name_list": ["Huw Jenkins"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020"]}, "381": {"ans_list": ["Certainly not right off! You\u2019d have an advantage, possibly, after the first year of surfing after you\u2019ve developed your back, shoulders and the skills to catch waves. The first few months as a novice surfer you\u2019d be learning how to paddle and catch waves, and your skateboarding skills would confer you no advantage at that. And the card game \u2018Bridge\u2019 hadn\u2019t been invented. :-) The Spartan\u2019s warrior ethos applied to the women as well as the men. Their population included a large percentage of slaves/helots who had to be intimidated and dominated if Spartan society was to function effectively. The Spartan women had to run the show while the warriors were out terrorizing the rest of ancient Greece. If the women weren\u2019t physically intimidating and didn\u2019t display their athletic strength o a regular basis, the slaves would revolt and that had to be avoided. using.\nThere are indoor volleyball and outdoor volleyball.\nIndoor volleyball traits and material:\nUsually made of some type of leather and most have some type of cover on top of it (for example, there\u2019s micro-fiber cover on the Mikasa MVA200)\nIndoor balls are molded together. The panels of the ball are all separate until they are glued onto an inner lining. This gives indoor balls a consistent and smooth texture.\nOutdoor volleyball traits and materials:\nOutdoor balls, also known as beach balls, are usually made of a composite material that can withstand water and resist constant friction of sand.\nOutdoor volleyballs are stitched together (if you look closely at a beach ball you will see the panels are attached together with threads)\nThey are stitched instead of just glued together because they need the extra resiliency. They need to be able to withstand constant exposure to the different outside elements!\nSo depending on the type of ball you are talking about, the material used to make it will be completely different.\nSource: Article written on Jump Brothers website", "The first layer (inner most) is made out of a rubber bladder. []}, "398": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["Handball", "Playing Sports", "Hands", "Sports", "Games", "Survey Question"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Anne Prescott", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "How long does it take your hands to get used to playing handball? Does it hurt a lot at first?", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": "101", "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "1335": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["error"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "", "no_of_follower": 0, "question_author": "", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "error", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": 0, "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "1138": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["error"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "", "no_of_follower": 0, "question_author": "", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "error", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": 0, "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "427": {"ans_list": ["I have a friend of mine who was a professional football player. According to his words, all players overreact to injuries in order to make referees brandish easy yellow cards. But he used to overreact in order to get some more seconds to relax and reload with energy. Imagine you are 90kg, you are playing as a striker as you always observe the offside line and make numerous runs, it is likely to lose stamina at some point.", "In international soccer, under FIFA Laws, there are no time outs and for the eleven starting players, there are only three substitutions allowed for the entire game.\nTherefore, by \u201cover reacting\u201d to the foul/injury, the player gains a little more time to be treated on the field before the player is removed from the field, the team plays short-handed and then the player is waved back onto the field by the referee.\nTherefore, the over reacting \u201cbuys more time\u201d and everyone, especially the injured player, gets an unofficial Time Out.\nSimple.", "Not sure how familiar you are with football (soccer) so excuse me if I've used simple terms. I watch a lot of football, so I think it's important to point out a distinction here. There are two things at play here: simulation and over-reaction.\nSimulation is the act of pretending to be fouled or embellishing contact to make a foul look worse. So, say a defender slide tackles an attacker, but makes no contact. If the attacker falls there, he is (usually) guilty of simulation (also called \"diving\"). This is illegal in the laws of the game, and is punished with a caution and an indirect free-kick to the other team. Players continue to do it, however, as they can sometimes win a penalty (spot kick at goal from 12 yards, with only the goalkeeper in the way) which is pretty much a guaranteed goal if the foul has taken place in the penalty box. The risk of caution + free-kick if you're caught doing it is generally small when weighed up against getting a penalty, so players keep doing it! It's also quite hard for the referees to spot sometimes, so may go unpunished.\nOver-reaction, which may be more what you're talking about, is when you see players completely over-react to contact that has been made, and he will roll around on the floor clutching his leg. This is not technically illegal in most cases, i.e. if you get hit in the leg and clutch your leg, nobody can really tell how much you've been hurt. However, if you get elbowed in the chest and hold your face, that is simulation, and the punishment as above is appropriate. The reason players over-react is basically two-fold: it's not technically illegal (unless it encroaches into simulation) and it exploits the fact that referees are human. If they see someone go down and rub their shin and get back up, then they will assume the contact is not bad. However, if the player stays down, and requires medical attention or looks to be in a lot of pain, then the referee will think that the contact is very bad and the punishment may be worse.\nI hope that cleared some things up.\nSimulation/diving can be used to win penalties/punishment for opposition players, over-reaction can colour the referees opinion of an incident.", "Easy question. A free kick or a penalty. If they get fouled in the box then they hey a penalty which is basically a free goal. If its a free kick then there is a chance of a goal if the kick is taken by a player who can curve.", "strategy to lose time", "Sometimes, they aren\u2019t over reacting, it does really hurt, the speed of soccer players running into each other/get tripped with high speed then falling on the ground hurts really bad. If you don't, you come up with a thoughtless response and misdirect. Right? A person with little or no experience won't know any better.\nBut, I got to tell you, everyone is different. Some people learn quickly, and some people need one-on-one guidance. So, it's important to know something about whomever you're talking to before you send them down a path. And, this question is asking for a path.\nThink about it:\nThis question doesn't convey a goal.\nThis question tells me nothing about where you are currently? \u201cLittle to no training\u201d? I don't even know what that means. Is it:\nkickboxing once a week? Or,\nwatching a boxing match on YouTube? Or,\nyou're an amateur boxer? Or,\nyou've been in a street fight or subject to one (in other words, you've taken a beating)?\nTo the question \u2014 if you want to learn to box, get into good physical condition, so when you join USA Boxing\n, you can hopefully find a coach worth your efforts; who can help you move in the direction of your goals. It takes a novice (someone with zero skills) at least 4 years to get it. It's like learning how to walk again. So, I'd work on:\nRunning\nWalking\nPush ups\nPull ups\nCrunches\nEtc.\nAnd, you don't have be an Adonis. You just have to be healthy, and build up a tolerance to pushing your limits, physically and mentally. With a good trainer, you'll break the old you, and shape who you become.\nI don't feel comfortable giving you anything to work on because you'd just build in bad habits you won't be able to shake during in training with your coach, and that's not fair to your coach. A tennis match can go on forever if the deciding set doesn\u2019t have a tie break. If the rule is to win the match in the deciding set with a difference of two games, then what happened at Wimbledon in 2010 could be repeated.\nIt was a first-round match between the American John Isner and the Frenchman Nicolas Mahut. That match lasted for a mammoth 11 hours and 5 minutes, completing over a span of three days. It was finally won by John Isner the score was 6\u20134, 3\u20136,6\u20137(7\u20139),7\u20136(7\u20133),70\u201368. Yes, that\u2019s right 70\u201368.\nBut these days the ATP is slowly doing away with this rule of the difference of two in the deciding set, as seen at the Australian Open this year where the deciding set had a tie-break, rather than the usual difference of two. But still a match can be never-ending if the players in the tie-break take it to 6\u20136 and no one wins two points continuously", "Yes & here are two tennis players who will agree. Match.\nSide story: Wimbledon had the nerve to pair these two again in Rd. 1 of the 2011 Event.", "Theoretically yes. You cannot win the final \u201cset\u201d in tennis without being 2 \u201cgames\u201d clear (and having won at least 6), which means that if the two players keep alternating winning games, theoretically the final set could go on indefinitely (obviously within reason, exhaustion and darkness would mean that of course the game doesn't just go on forever). The nature of sports mean this would never happen, but there have been several very long tennis games, lasting 4+ hours!\nTie breaks also require the 2 points clear, so could go on indefinitely."], "topic_list": ["Tennis Match", "Tennis Players", "Tennis", "Sports"], "view_list": [15, 17, 24], "create_time": "Apr 22, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Andreas Badi", "upvote_list": [1, 0, 0], "question_title": "Can a tennis match go on forever?", "respond_collected": 3, "no_of_view": "482", "name_list": ["Ashish Burade", "James Ward", "D Snelling"], "date_list": ["Apr 24, 2020", "Apr 22, 2020", "Apr 22, 2020"]}, "1339": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["error"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "", "no_of_follower": 0, "question_author": "", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "error", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": 0, "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "471": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["Female Athletes", "Track and Field", "College Sports", "Athletes", "Athletics", "Olympic Games", "Professional Athletes", "Running (activity)", "Professional Sports", "Sports"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "Apr 25, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Kailash Pradhan", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "Which female runner has been elected a member of the athletes Commission of the Asian Athletics Association (AAA)?", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": "35", "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "1530": {"ans_list": [], "topic_list": ["error"], "view_list": [], "create_time": "", "no_of_follower": 0, "question_author": "", "upvote_list": [], "question_title": "error", "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": 0, "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "88": {"ans_list": ["As a teen, I think you should, but in a different way. Reward them the game disk. I am sure 4 disk a year is afforable.", "This eternal question about rewarding children for their successes is important because parents always want to know how to motivate their children to do their best, to strive, to want to be successful, to win, to achieve, and to be motivated.\nThe science of Motivation - Wikipedia\nis described in detail in a comprehensive, well written, and well researched Wikipedia article.\nI would like to focus your attention in particular on the subject of intrinsic and extrinsic motivation. When parents reward their child for doing well, it is an extrinsic reward. And when children do well because of the feeling of satisfaction they get by accomplishing a goal through their own hard work, with no other reinforcement \u2014 that feeling is intrinsic motivation.\nWhen learning and accomplishment are their own rewards, the learner/actor is capable of using their own inner drive/desire/motivation to keep on learning, to continue accomplishing.\nI know a man who was CEO of a successful corporation. It was part of his job to help the Director of Sales increase sales. They discovered something very interesting. The sales people weren\u2019t sufficiently motivated by money (their salary plus commission). The sales staff were not motivated by state of the art TV or electronics or computers. The only thing that motivated the sales force was the high esteem of the other salespeople. So the CEO and the Director of Sales designed a contest.\nEach salesperson was enrolled in a contest. The ones who exceeded their monthly sales quota had their photo professionally framed, it hung on the wall where the entire company and all clients could see it \u2014 their portrait, their name, their identity honored as \u201cSalesman of the Month.\u201d The salesperson of the month after a year were a group of about five, the best of the sales staff. They had a private dinner with the CEO. Photos were taken and published. All the other salespeople were envious and tried harder. Sales increased tremendously.\nAfter a year they needed another contest. So they designed a way to create an incentive travel contest. Spouses and significant others were included by sending mailers home touting the destination and asking for the home team to root for their significant other\u2019s sales successes.\nAfter a year of Tahiti-themed events each month, photos of Bora Bora and Morea all over the sales room, and photos of sales staff placed strategically near maps of Tahiti and snorkels and masks on the walls as art, everyone was asking each other: \u201cWill you be the one on the beach this winter?\u201d The sales staff were in a frenzy. Wives and husbands and significant others at home were asking every day: \u2018\u2018Will we be the lucky ones and be able to go to Tahiti?\u2019\nAll these people wanted was to be able to have the dopamine/esteem advantage (competitively) over their fellow salespeople.\n\u2014-\nCompare that kind of a competition and the system of extrinsic rewards / bribery with another way. Think of someone who is intrinsically rewarded and who seeks excellence naturally because of the intrinsic feelings of satisfaction and accomplishment that competence and success bring.\nJakob (name changed for privacy) had a great learning coach. Jakob\u2019s coach liked Jakob and taught him how to use positive self talk to persevere when facing a challenging concept, idea, or problem. Jakob was directly and explicitly taught executive functioning skills useful for learning, organizing, memorizing, studying, and solving problems.\nJakob liked the learning coach and was interested and excited to learn with a teacher like that. Jakob looked forward to their times together. The only reward was Jakob\u2019s increasing comprehension, literacy, numeracy, and composition skills.\nJakob was internally motivated. He is amazing and it is because he learned how to learn, how to be self motivated, And how to use the tools he has to learn more.", "External rewards are helpful in the absence of internal motivation. All novices need external rewards because it\u2019s almost impossible to be internally motivated when you\u2019re brand new and really horrible at something.\nIt is completely ok to start kids/people off with external motivation until they get some skills and become internally motivated.\nWhen someone is already internally motivated, offering external rewards can be detrimental to their internal motivation. So definitely stop giving rewards when there\u2019s internal motivation.\nFinally, you can reward kids with other things besides toys. Like verbal praise, quality time with you or with friends, trips, hikes, swimming. All sorts of things. If you like, try some of these out and see if they work. :)", "you don't continue doing that for the rest of their lives.\nI think my parents stopped at the end of middle school. I\u2019ll touch the wave tips of what I look for when I\u2019m assessing draft prospects for \u201cmy\u201d NBA team, the Toronto Raptors.\nSpeed and quickness.\nSpeed refers to the ability to keep up with the blinding pace of pro hoops. If you are the last one down the floor almost every time, don\u2019t expect to make the final cut.\nQuickness refers to what you do in the first quarter-second after the man you are covering changes hands on the dribble. Can you adjust, or is he by you, and on his way to the hoop? There are countless other examples.\nBody type.\nI pay great attention to extremities. A big man with average-sized feet won\u2019t survive. It\u2019s no coincidence that two of the greatest swingmen ever, Julius Erving and Kawhi Leonard, are blessed with huge hands.\nA big chest is likely to present a problem. Not only will you suffer by not enjoying free arm movement, you will be carrying extra weight. The stress on your joints may lead to injuries.\nContinuing with the upper body - is it too big for your legs? A long trunk with (relatively) short legs may be fine for an NFL lineman, but isn\u2019t for a basketball player.\nFitness level. At training camp, if you are panting after a half-hour, that\u2019s a problem. Your mind will be thinking about how to preserve its oxygen level, not how to defend, or run the variant of the next offensive play. Chunky players risk being cut.\nShooting skill. In today\u2019s NBA, if you can\u2019t score, you can\u2019t play. I am highly skeptical of the notion that coaches can \u201cfix\u201d a fundamentally unsound jump shot.\nBasketball intelligence [BI]. Assessing this \u201csoft\u201d skill is a giant task. There are so many facets: charges taken, assists, opposition passes deflected, steals, turnovers, guards\u2019 rebounds\u2026.\nBI cannot be determined by statistics. You must see the player in games, over and over. Just on assists: how many does your point guard (let\u2019s say) prospect not get credit for because his teammates can\u2019t shoot, and how many \u201chockey assists\u201d does he get? Those kinds of things don\u2019t show up in stat sheets, yet can be invaluable in assessing hidden gems.\nThe question asks specifically about determining who will blossom into a star. I\u2019ve chosen a more modest response, one in which I tell you how I decide who is going to get a training camp invitation. Stardom can\u2019t happen until you are on a roster.\nI hope this helps.", "Basketball is first and foremost a game of athleticism. Size strength speed quickness vertical jump. A second component is the feel for the game. The anticipation of movement and timing- these are also innate skills refined through practice and games. If a player is dominant in college with some combination of the aforementioned skills it's likely he will be good in the league. Zion is a good example. No. Preserved and included within the HOF, yes.", "No. While no one with a brain doubts that many members of the old Negro Leagues would have been first ballot HOFers, two leagues are separate entities.\nQ: Should Negro League record books be combined with Major League Baseball record books?", "No, they are separate leagues. This is not a slam on The Negro Leagues, they may very well have been better than the Majors at that time. Either way they are separate leagues and in My opinion should have separate statistics.", "Unfortunately, no.\nWe simply don\u2019t have sufficient records to do this. The mainstream newspapers rarely covered black ball and wouldn\u2019t have bothered with the box scores. The black newspapers rarely could send correspondents out on the road and even locally the papes were more likely to print just line scores. The organized Negro leagues did not keep careful records and of course to survive they had to play a lot of exhibition games and such. The data we would need simply doesn\u2019t exist and there\u2019s no way to retrieve it.\nIt is tragic, to be sure. An important and fascinating part of baseball heritage is lost.\nMy sense of the Negro leagues is that they were overall probably about Triple A level at a time when Triple A was a bit closer to the majors than today. And of course any number of Negro leaguers would have been able to play in the majors and many would have been stars except for bad career choices\u2014namely to be born black when they did not have a fair chance. For that matter, if we were discussing the greatest catcher only and you wanted to name Josh Gibson, I wouldn\u2019t argue with you. Typically, the race takes place on a standard 400-metre or 1/4-mile running track. The race begins at the 1-mile starting line with the consumption of a 12-US-fluid-ounce beer, followed by a full lap around the track. The second lap continues in a similar manner; another 12-ounce beer is consumed before commencing the running of the second lap. This process is repeated for the next two laps. Following the completion of the fourth running lap, a competitor has finished the race. More specific rules of the race vary by region. In North America, typically, 12 US ounces of beer is consumed from a can or bottle before every lap. A set of rules has been defined and published by The Official Beer Mile Resource\n.", "Pankration (mma) used to be included in ancient times.\nI would make the main event trying to discover the best athlete in the planet.
