For those lucky enough to work their matches, both Federer and Nadal stood out to them as being particularly gracious and making their job easier.\nOne thing that fans may not know however is that only THE BEST ballkids tend to work the matches featuring the top players, so these pros are more likely to be pleased with the ballkids because they are the best ballkids.\nBut overall, the general attitude of the pros is that they are grateful for the ballkids. They realize that the kids and most of the staff at a tournament are voluntering their time FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE PLAYERS.\nThis general impression can be overshadowed because BAD incidents get noteriety, for instance when a player will get exasperated with a ballkid or they chastise the ballkid for a delay in bringing the towel.\nTaking the ballkids for granted does happen but it tends to be a minority of players.\nThe three that stand out for me as being a ballkid\u2019s nightmare are Maria Sharapova, Sachia Vickery and Richard Gasquet.\nSharapova does not acknowledge a ballkid unless they do something wrong, and she puts them in a position where that is more likely.\nUnlike the great majority of players, Sharapova only wanted to receive balls only from one side when she is serving. There are 2 ballkids in the back of the court who usually have all 6 balls between them for the server.\nShe wants all the balls to come from only one of those ballkids and if they forget or are slow in getting them all to that one ballkid, she gets mad. The ballkids are always on edge when she is playing, and felt under pressure.\nSachia Vickery has a well-deserved reputation on the WTA tour for gamesmanship, like acting as if she is injured between points and then running everything down once the point starts. She tends to turn every match into a situation where everyone is out to get her, from her opponent to the umpire and this even extends to the ballkids. She is just in a foul mood on court and it reflects in her behavior towards the ballkids.\nGasquet is one of those players who just does not acknowledge a ballkid\u2019s existence , but at the same time expect them to be his slaves.\nHe has a unique habit of changing the grip on his racket every changeover, and he takes the old grip and all the packaging and just throws it over his shoulder from his seat on the bench for a ballkid to pick up his trash and get it into the nearby trashcan.\nBut they are the exceptions!!\nIt\u2019s now become a tradition at almost every tournament, including Indian Wells, for the champions of the tournament to spend some time taking photographs with the ballkids at the end of a tournament, in part as a measure of thanks.\nAnd at Indian Wells there is a banquet to thank and reward all the volunteers including the ballkids after the tournament is over.\nThere is absolutely no one who manages, organizes, trains, and acts as ballkids who gets paid - it\u2019s all volunteers.\nThe irony is that the great majority of staff and ballkids are gone by the 2nd week of a tournament, they are not around to get that praise.\nAs the tournament progresses, there are less and less matches so only the most senior staff and the most experienced, top-rated (We grade the ballkids every match!!) ballkids are left when the tournament concludes.\nA last way that the players can show their appreciation is at the conclusion of any tournament the players are surveyed to judge how staff, and even ballkids, performed in the tournament.\nSupposedly, for many years IW had the highest ratings of any tournament on tour. But now what the Grand Slams are doing, particularly the US Open, is requiring ballkids to be older, and I think as a result Indian Wells has increased their minimum age requirement. ["Contrary to popular belief, there is no limit to your height or weight that stops you from practicing parkour. Lighter people generally find it easier, however I know of some heavily-built people who are more skilled than many of your typical wiry, lean ninja types.\nHeight and weight don\u2019t matter. What really influences your parkour ability, especially for a beginner, is your strength compared to your body weight. If you\u2019re someone who is extremely light, but with lean muscle and a low body fat percentage, parkour will be considerably easier for you. If you are someone who is heavy-set but strong, you will also have less trouble starting parkour than someone who is heavy with low muscle mass.\nAt the end of the day, none of this really stops you from doing parkour. "respond_collected": 0, "no_of_view": 0, "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "407": {"ans_list": ["Interesting question that I did not know but found some cool info. I knew it had to be from the first Olympics held in 1896 in Athens Greece.\nThe US had only 14 competitors but they won 11 gold medals and a total of 20 medals overall.\nHere is the link: 1896 Olympics", "The first American to win an Olympic Gold for the marathon was Thomas Hicks at the St Louis Games in 1904. He was born in England but was clearly a US citizen\u2014he was a brass worker in Cambridge, Massachusetts.\nThe course was described as a \u201cdirt track\u201d and the conditions \u201cappalling\u201d with dust being thrown up by the race officials\u2019 vehicles on a hot, dry day and this was reflected in the times with Hicks finishing in 3:28:53 which was comfortably the slowest winning time in any Olympic marathon. Despite the conditions there was only one watering-point provided during the race.\nHicks actually crossed the line in second place as another US runner, Fred Lorz, was first to finish, but he was disqualified because it appears he had dropped out of the race after 9 miles and \u2018hitched\u2019 a lift in a car back to the stadium. The car broke down at the 19-mile point and Lorz started running again and made it to the finishing point. Officials were about to present him with the medal when the truth was revealed. Though he claimed he\u2019d done it for a joke he was banned for a year; but he did come back to win the Boston Marathon in 1905.\nGoing back to Hicks; although he was leading by a mile and a half with 10 miles to go he was ready to drop out but was \u2018revived\u2019 by a small dose of strychnine in brandy. he struggled on. The strychnine dose was repeated and eventually he was helped over the finishing line by members of his \u2018support team\u2019 (literally in this case). Needless to say, in a later era, he would have been disqualified and banned on at least two counts. He was fortunate in fact that he didn\u2019t kill himself with a combination of strychnine, heat exhaustion and dehydration.\nTwo more US runners Albert Corey and Arthur Newton took silver and bronze, respectively.\nThere is a fine Wikipedia account of the final which is well worth a read.\nAthletics at the 1904 Summer Olympics \u2013 Men's marathon - Wikipedia", "Frank Shorter in 1972 with a time Some yell, scream and intimidate because it works, at first. When adrenaline is flowing students hit harder and run faster\u2014they are in fight or flight mode. It is worse in the team competitive sports such a football and basketball, the ones that most people assume are important. Almost all hockey is played in leagues outside of schools, and other sports should probably imitate that model, because coaches are either good at increasing the performance of their team, or good at teaching\u2014it is extremely rare to see one who can do both.", "I can\u2019t help you with this. My coaches were never bullies.", "Not every coach yelled and screamed. My track / cross country coach was very mellow very encouraging and explained to us why we did each workout. I can say the same for many of my little league base ball and football coaches. Do not confuse pushing with fake intimidation and some yelling with bullying to get more effort. IMO coaches who were bullies would put the smallest v largest in one on one drills for blood lust. I never had a coach threaten me or my team mates with harm They never made us do something until everybody puked. We never did runs in double sweats in the hot sun. These kind of things are bullying. The \u201cscience\u201d is in the defense and learning to throw combinations of punches without exposing yourself.\nHowever, it\u2019s easier said then done and takes an incredible amount of hard, grueling training and discipline to be come good at it.", "Because it is. If brute strength was all that was required-then we\u2019d only need a heavyweight division, and The guys who could hit hard and take a punch would dominate. Ed \u201cToo Tall\u201d Jones 6\u20329\u2033 and 280 a fearsome defensive end for the Dallas Cowboys, and Mark Gastineau a 6\u20325\u2033 270 lb defensive lineman for the New York Jets both tried their hand at pro boxing and failed miserably against much smaller guys, who were nobodies. They learned that hitting a Quarterback who isn\u2019t looking while trying to throw a ball 40 yards downfield is a lot different than hitting a pro fighter who\u2019s hitting back! There\u2019s skill, and balance, and footwork required. And strategy-cutting off the ring, counter-punching, defense. The \u201cRocky\u201d movies caused the public to get the wrong idea completely. \u201cRocky Balboa\u201d got hit way too much, and took too much punishment. Watch film of Sugar Ray Robinson, Sonny Liston-not two minute clips of the Ali-fights-Joe Louis, Sugar Ray Leonard-their head movement, their footwork, their balance is amazing. I had a reputation as a slugger-I had KO power in either hand. I wasn\u2019t Sugar Ray Leonard, but I could box better than people thought. And yes, I could take a punch-what 210 lb Irishman can\u2019t? But I didn\u2019t get hit that often. The Great Archie Moore-who was light-heavyweight champ in the \u201850\u2019s and fought Floyd Patterson, Ezzard Charles, Rocky Marciano-and a young Cassius Clay-was my trainer for a while. He taught me to bob and weave, and to \u201croll\u201d with punches-Roberto Duran was a master of this. You could hit me ( or Duran ) but not full-force-because I was already moving away when it landed. I used to watch film of my opponents. One of my greatest amateur victories was over a jerk who was 32 years old, had had over 100 amateur fights and never turned pro. I was 19, and had had about 15 fights when I was matched with this guy in a Golden Gloves tournament. Archie and I watched film. He had a habit of dipping his left shoulder before he threw a left hook, which was his best shot. In the 2nd round I stepped inside and nailed him with an uppercut that would make Mike Tyson proud. His head hit the canvas before his ass did, and he was being given smelling salts while I was getting the trophy. He knew my uncle-and told my uncle-\u201dYour nephew got lucky\u201d My uncle laughed and responded-\u201dNo, he watched film of you, and found your weakness.\u201d \u201cHe threw that punch twice in the 1st round, and barely missed.\u201d \u201cIt just took him a little time to find the range.\u201d \u201cAnd since you were out for 10 minutes and they called the paramedics-either my nephew is George Foreman, or your not the \u201cbadass\u201d you claim to be!! People think car racing and bull-riding is easy too. Their not.", "Because it is.\nTry facing even a moderately skilled amateur and you will be on the receiving end of multiple punches to your body and head, and you won\u2019t see most of them coming.\nI\u2019ve played all the major sports, and have been blessed with good hand-eye coordination and excellent reflexes and hand speed. I can tell you with absolute confidence that no sport requires more skill, reflexes, stamina, and courage (and I regularly run road races and marathons).\nTry sparring with a trusted pugilist friend for a full three rounds (at the amateur length of two minutes: the professionals go 12 rounds-15 in the recent past-at three minutes each round (not the two the amateurs do), and I guarantee you will be hard pressed to finish two rounds: you\u2019ll get pummeled in the third and find it impossible to even keep your hands up (that\u2019s why you should only face a trusted boxer friend or coach-it\u2019s too dangerous for a beginner to face anyone. You will get hurt unless you\u2019re sparring with someone who is experienced and knows how to keep from hurting you).\nThe lack of stamina (and inability to defend yourself after one or two rounds) is only the beginning. You will have no idea how to defend yourself from multiple blows that come from every angle. You will be shocked at the speed and power of your opponent (\u201cman, that little guy really can punch\u201d)-and you\u2019ll be further amazed (and frustrated) at how difficult it is to hit your opponent.\nTry running around the ring to get away from the punishment? Your opponent will have learned how to cut off the ring. You\u2019ll be cornered in no time and be crying, \u201cNo mas!\u201d without a hint of dignity.\nPeople look at Ali or Tyson or any number of incredible boxers and think, \u201cI can do that. What\u2019s the big deal?\u201d\nIt\u2019s a huge deal. From stamina, to quickness, to defense, to body mechanics, to strength (and a million other things) boxing is really, really mentally difficult (never mind quieting the fear that most boxers continue to face stepping into that ring standing across someone who wants to knock your head off).\nMiss swinging at a baseball? Oh, well. I struck out.\nMiss a jump shot in basketball? Eh. No big deal.\nDrop a pass in football or a blocking assignment? Coach is going to yell, but I\u2019ll survive.\nLose your attention for a moment in boxing?\nIf your opponent is skilled, you\u2019ll be punched so hard you\u2019ll see stars, and probably get knocked out.\nNobody-and I mean nobody-steps into a ring and is instantly a professional. Talk to boxers, and they\u2019ll talk all day about the multiple, multiple skills they\u2019ve learned (and what they continue to learn).\nFighters spend years of training to gain some knowledge of the sweet science we call \u201cboxing.\u201d", "Because it's all about physics basically. It's about reading your opponent. Anticipating what your opponent is going to do. You also have to get into your opponent's head. So basically there's a lot of science behind it.", "The Old Time Fighters of the 1930\u2032s and 40\u2032s called Boxing The Sweet Science. This was because of the skills and the pure Brutality of the sport.", "It was actually called the sweet science and was taught to gentlemen along with sword fighting as self defense. The object of boxing is to hit and not get hit , very simple.", "because it is", "Boxing has been called many things, including \u201cthe sweet science\u201d and \u201cmanly art of self-defense.\u201d The words \u201cart\u201d and \u201cscience\u201d suggests that to be successful in the sport, a pugilist requires intellectual analysis and the tactical skill that is becoming of an art form.", "As noted, for years boxing was referred to as the \u201csweet science\u201d\u2026.\nBut at the very same time, it might have been called an \u201cart\u201d as well. As in \u201cthe manly art of self-defense\u201d.\nIt\u2019s just idiom.", "Just a quick thought. All sports can be called a science because they incorporate scienctific principles of body movement/mechanics such as torque, levers, axis, force, etc. as well as using principles of Kinesiology, Physiology, strategy and tactics. As a former Physical Educator, most of my college courses were science based including medical science like biology, anatomy, etc. ; pretty much a pre-med curriculum. Degrees in Physical Education & sports science are designated as a BS (Bachelor of Science), MS (Master of Science), as well as a PHD in which the sciences of all sports and their movements, effects on the body, preparation for the greatest efficiency, and so on are all considered scientifically. Why boxing alone is called a science, I can only guess that it stems from the history of pugilism where training/conditioning, strategy, etc. was always highly considered as science based.", "Often called the \u201csweet science\u201d to be exact. Due to the skill the mastery of offense and defense and the angles of attack both on offense and defense. When performed at the highest level it's done only by those that have an aptitude, intelligence and capability and to do so requires mastery of a science.\nTo me it's defined as the science of how to hit and not get hit but the true challenge is to do it in a manner that excites the crowd. Its name is derived from the path the ball takes: if you were looking overhead, the path of the ball traces a \u201cZ.\u201d\nIf hit with enough pace, the z-serve will hit the second side wall and will pop straight towards the receiver in a line parallel to the back wall.\nThe below image depicts a hard Z serve perfectly (image from Key Racquetball 3.6 Drive Service Zones\n)"], "topic_list": It is still the forest and most efficient way to fairly start a race because it gives no one an advantage. It also is a little startling so it helps starts.", "Starter pistols and canon fire blanks and usually have a barrel without the bore and rifling that would allow passage of a bullet. Their purpose is to generate a single sharp loud sound to signal the instant start of a race to participants and observers. The blank may also emit a puff of smoke so that observers distant from the starter gun can see the instant of its firing without any time lag caused by the speed of sound.", "Signify the beginning of a match, game, race."], "topic_list": ["Target Shooting", "Pistols", "Sports Business", "Roles and Responsibilities", "Handguns", "Professional Athletes", "Professional Sports", "Weapons", "Guns and Firearms", "Sports"], "view_list": [363, 15, 31, 3], "create_time": "Apr 21, 2020", "no_of_follower": 2, "question_author": "Hannah Baker", "upvote_list": [1, 0, 1, 0], "question_title": "What is the role of a starter pistol in sports?", "respond_collected": 4, "no_of_view": "910", "name_list": ["Thom Silverstein", "Bill Brown", "John Shea", "Tait Rief"], "date_list": ["Apr 22, 2020", "Apr 21, 2020", "Apr 21, 2020", "Apr 21, 2020"]}, "34": {"ans_list": ["This is the blog of my Sifu Ralph Haenel where he related a bit about some of his sihings. "name_list": [], "date_list": []}, "387": {"ans_list": ["No, that will never happen. They are completely different categories, and even if F1 would go electric someday, it would still be the pinnacle of motorsport.\nIn a race, a Formula E car would get absolutely destroyed by even a backmarker Formula 1 car. The reason is simple. Formula E cars aren't really designed to be the fastest cars in the world. The cars are capped at 250 kW (~ 335 HP), which on street circuits is enough. Because of this relatively low max power output, the racing is a lot closer.\nThe aero bits on Formula E cars are pretty simple as well. Most of the downforce is generated by those massive rear diffusers, which don't affect the car behind the car as much as F1's huge wings, while the upper portion of the chassis doesn't really have a front or rear wing; those are replaced with small winglets. And as all the cars have a spec chassis, the main performance difference between the cars (excluding Fan Boost and Attack Mode) is the squidgy organic bit in the middle.\nThere is no denying that electric cars will become the norm in motorsport in a few decades, but as of now, they are both are the pioneers of their own areas. Formula 1 is constantly pushing the limits of what you can achieve with a small, hybrid engine while Formula E is showcasing batteries that you could find in your car in a few years.\nSome text source: Aditya Devendran", "Unlikely. They will at some point may be able to go as quick as F1, but by then the F1 will be at the top of absolute physical limitations what the cars and the human drivers can do.\nIt's a completely caveats.\nFor many years, the PGA tour has set a minimum number of tour events at 15. That is the fewest you can play and stay within their rules. And all types of events count - majors, WGC events, Ryder Cup, playoffs.\nThere is a relatively new rule for Tour players as well but it has myriad stipulations. Any player playing in less than 25 events who is not a lifetime member (20+ wins and a minimum of 15 years on Tour), achieved veteran status (at least 45 years old), or have dual status on the PGA Tour/PGA Tour Champions, MUST schedule at least one event annually that they have not played in the last 4 seasons.\nSo if Joe Golfer is 37 and has 4 tour wins and is only planning on playing 22 events this season, one of those events MUST be an event he hasn\u2019t played in at least 4 seasons. This stipulation doesn\u2019t affect many golfers as many of them have played or will play over 25 events. And it has no effect on the guys it might be meant to bring to venues they don\u2019t normally play, like Tiger or Phil. A lot of the appeal is just the atmosphere of the track (the food, the people and the fact that the racers are typically local). You aren\u2019t going to find superstars here, but you are close to the action, and the speeds are fast, but not so fast that there isn\u2019t a lot of back and forth action between the cars. You can also get an easy view of the entire track. You pretty much have to experience this in person.\nThe large oval racetracks are quite different. I\u2019ve been to one NASCAR race and one Formula 1 race, so I\u2019m no expert. The aficionados with their RVs no doubt enjoy the atmosphere in those areas as well. The Formula 1 race I attended was exciting, but I only got a view of a very small section of track and the cars went by so fast I couldn\u2019t really see them. For the NASCAR race I sat really high in the stands to get a great view of the track, but even so I found the noise to be deafening. I couldn\u2019t interact with my family and friends I was there with, except during the yellow flags. Yes, you see superstars (at a great distance) and it can be exciting, but I personally found this to be the least enjoyable. I much prefer to watch these races on TV.\nRally racing is a different beast. It\u2019s probably my favorite format of all. It brings insane driving skill together with mechanics that must be able to do rapid repairs to the vehicles, and the ability to closely follow course directions. I\u2019ve attended rally races at various levels all the way up to WRC. The problem is that in person you don\u2019t get a great view of the action. You pick on spot and you see all the cars go through for your small section, but you don\u2019t get to see any of the rest of the race. On the other hand, you can get ridiculously close to the action and the teams are incredibly approachable. Coverage of these races on TV allows for a better view of the overall race, but due to the length of the race (it usually lasts 3 days) and the fact that it takes place over the course of hundreds of miles of roads, you are mostly relying on small clips and in-car cameras.\nSo where does this leave us with respect to electric cars participating in these races?\nThe primary example we have today is Formula E. It\u2019s very similar to Formula 1 in that the format is on a large race circuit. I particularly find watching Formula E on TV to be very fascinating. I like all the data and stats that are presented on screen and can see the strategy the teams use. I don\u2019t think it would be as exciting to see these races in person, but compared to watching actual Formula 1, or NASCAR, the lack of ridiculous levels of sound would be welcome.\nFor the local track type of races, I think it will be quite some time (if ever) before we see electric cars participating. I will admit that in this setting, the sound and smell is a big part of the atmosphere. So in this case, I would have to admit that electric car stock racing might not be as exciting/enjoyable.\nFinally for rally racing: with today\u2019s technology I think it is impractical to have electric vehicles competing. The distances are just too far. However, if it were technically possible to do a battery exchange or something like that after each stage or two, I actually think that electric rally racing could be even more enjoyable. Following the data in addition to the race progress would be really cool. I would really like to see this some day.", "No.", "F1 used to have refueling stops which took abot 3 seconds but on one occasion the pipe was left connected when the driver set off. Don\u2019t get me wrong, I would LOVE to have a Tesla P100D. I would drive the wheels off of it. But it wouldn\u2019t beat an equally fast sports car in my book.\nHave you ever been to a drag strip? There is something about the roar of a late model Corvette with twin turbos bringing the nose up as it takes off. Nothing like seeing an old Fox Mustang with turbos going 150 MPH or more in a quarter mile. That sweet smell of race fuel and burned rubber. The roar of the engines as they get staged and hit the trans brake, the squeal of the car leaving the burnout box. It gets your heart racing. There is something about the lack of refinement of those cars that makes them beautiful.\nHow about NASCAR? 800 hp going 175 mph in a circle, roaring and rattling your eardrums as they pass? Art, in its broadest sense, is a form of communication. It means whatever the artist intends it to mean, and this meaning is shaped by the materials, techniques, and forms it makes use of, as well as the ideas and feelings it creates in its viewers. That sounds like Wrestling to me.\nWrestlers tell stories/communication, the story is short term or long term, and it is shaped by the chapters we call matches, that use ideas to convey feelings to its viewers. \u201cART\u201d\nIn answering another question I told about I guy I knew who wanted to start a FANS WRESTLING SCHOOL, for $150 dollars he would give them three 1 hour sessions. []}, "9": {"ans_list": ["Typically full matriculation at an undergraduate institution includes a pass to use the gym, outside of certain periods. So the answer is generally yes. You won\u2019t be able to commandeer other students to use as wrestling or tennis or fencing partners, but you can probably find some who\u2019d like to practice something with you.", "All of them", "Well, not exactly, but sort of. Allow me to explain.\nYou could informally practice a sport, with friends or intramural college teams or a team outside of your college or whatever then if you feel confident you\u2019re good enough try out for the official intercollegiate team of your school. In all honesty, this is only going to work very well with smaller schools, especially some of the NAIA programs and possibly NCAA Div-III. It would be surprising if anyone went from a novice to able to try out and make an intercollegiate Div-I or even Div-II NCAA team, however."], "topic_list": ["Team Sports", "Playing Sports", "College Sports", "Sports", "The College and University Experience"], "view_list": [20, 2, 48], "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Emma O'Malley Galvan", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 1], "question_title": "Will colleges allow you to practice a sport you aren\u2019t good at/we\u2019re never exposed to? They are:\nArizona Coyotes (formerly the Winnipeg Jets)\nBuffalo Sabres\nColumbus Blue Jackets\nFlorida Panthers\nMinnesota Wild\nNashville Predators\nOttawa Senators\nSan Jose Sharks\nVancouver Canucks\nVegas Golden Knights\nWinnipeg Jets (formerly the Atlanta Thrashers)"], "topic_list": ["Stanley Cup", "National Hockey League", "Hockey", "Sports"], "view_list": [11, 19], "create_time": "Apr 21, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Juhi Anshu", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "question_title": "What teams have never won a Stanley Cup?", "respond_collected": 2, "no_of_view": "165", "name_list": ["David Hood", "William Kozy"], "date_list": ["Apr 22, 2020", "Apr 22, 2020"]}, "503": {"ans_list": ["No they go hand in hand. You have to be very good at both"], "topic_list": ["Ice Skating", "Ice Hockey", "Hockey", "Sports"], "view_list": [19], "create_time": "Apr 28, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Michael LeFevre", "upvote_list": [1], "question_title": "Is it true that to be an ice hockey official, skating ability takes priority over rule knowledge and application?", "respond_collected": 1, "no_of_view": "171", "name_list": ["Charlie Ralston"], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020"]}, "804": {"ans_list": ["From the most recent backward, four names immediately jump out at me:\nWladimir Klitschko\nTommy Morrison\nGerry Cooney\nRocky Marciano\nHowever brief, they were all great, white and hopeful before fighting for, or winning the championship.\nHonorable mention:\nJoe Calzaghe\nGene Tunney\nJack Dempsey\nWillie Pep", "I believe it was a man named Gerald Arthur Cooney. He was a heavyweight Contender from 1977 thu 1990. He fought twice for the heavyweight championship of the world. Once in 1982 and the other time in 1987", "I\u2019d probably say Vitali historically (wait for it), before he had won a legit title, specifically when got his face mashed up by Lennox.\nBut once he won a recognised title, his GWH status became fully redundant, so today you cant really class him as one. Someone with a title doesnt need hope to get one anymore!\nGWH is a stupid term anyway for a fan of all boxing, its just a tool to sell to the ignorant, which I might have been I guess when I was a kid chewing hype for Cooney vs Holmes, but I seem to recall that even back then I knew it was a farce of a phrase. A lot of these hopes were hypes really, people should have focused on zero demarcation by colour to focus on improving boxing quality.", "The Great White Hope debate. I have to say it rather proves that most posters on this subject are American as the dominant response has been about Tommy Morrison (which is reasonable enough as he comes under this heading, RIP). This debate is singled out for Heavyweights, so, leaving aside the \u2018great white hopes\u2019 of the past, i.e., Dempsey, Marciano et al, I would like to say:\nHave you forgotten Vladimir and Vitali Klitschko? Just because they aren\u2019t from the USA doesn\u2019t mean they fail to qualify. Of course, they were more than just \u2018great white hopes\u2019 because they actually achieved; winning multiple World Titles between them. Despite Vladimir\u2019s longevity in the heavyweight ranks and his overall fight record, I recognise Vitali as the better fighter. Far stronger chin and tighter fighting ability, as he showed against Lennox Lewis (albeit in Lewis\u2019 retirement fight).\nAnd the final argument on this is Tyson Fury. The hunt for the \u2018Great White Hope\u2019 is finally over. He\u2019s just not American. Sorry guys", "This is a term that time needs to pass by! I have been a boxing fan since a young guy in elementary school and guys would talk about Mickey Mantle and Rocky Marciano. I was a Rocky fan , not a white fighter fan.When Floyd m Patterson was champion I was a fan of his. When he lost briefly to a white swede ( Ingemar Johansson) I b still was a fan of Floyd because he was American. Being from Kentucky I of course was a fan of Muhammad Ali.The trouble with white hopes n is it brings up bad racial memories where blacks were denied opportunities they should have had ( although boxing has better qualifications than many other sports like baseball)", "Tommy Morrison, unfortunately he succumbed to drugs and HIV, he was up to fight Tyson.", "The last \u201cGreat White Hope\u201d was Gerry Cooney in 1982. Just for purposes of review, a \u201cgreat white hope\u201d is when most of the White boxing fans tire of having a Black heavyweight champion of hope for someone White to come along and beat him. The first time it happened was back when Jack Johnson was the heavyweight champion; he was the first Black heavyweight champion in fact. He was a great one, too. But he was too cocky for the taste of many White boxing fans. Since there was no active White heavweight fighter around who stood a chance to beat Johnson at the time, they talked a retired White heavyweight champion out of retirement - Jim Jeffries. Jeffries was a great champion who had retired undefeated. He had been out of boxing for six years, and was happy on his alfalfa farm, but there were too many who goaded him into feeling obligated to return to boxing and \u201ctake back\u201d the title from the Black champion for the sake of America.\nIn 1910, Johnson easily beat Jeffries in humiliating fashion. Jeffries was way out of shape, having to lose 100 pounds. Johnson knocked down Jeffries twice - something which had never been done - before Jeffries\u2019 corner threw in the towel in the 15th round. The result led to race riots all over America. Twenty-three Blacks and 2 Whites reportedly died. It would be five years before another \u201cGreat White Hope\u201d, Jess Willard, finally beat Johnson in 1915. Twenty-two years would pass before America would have another Black heavyweight boxing champion, that being the popular Joe Louis, who hold the title for the next 12 years. From 1952 - 1956 the great Rock Marciano was a White heavyweight boxing champion but he was not a \u201cGreat White Hope\u201d since he had no great Black opponent to unseat.\nIn 1956, Floyd Patterson, who was Black, won the heavyweight title and briefly lost it in 1960 to Ingemar Johansson, who was White, but who was from Sweden. Patterson would later win back the title, and no one seriously saw Johansson as a \u201cGreat White Hope.\u201d Beginning in 1960, Black men would hold the heavyweight box title for the next 33 years, when Tommy Morrison won and briefly held the WBO heavyweight box ing title. However, Tommy was not a \u201cGreat White Hope.\u201d There was a never an undisputed Black champion that the general White public wanted him to beat.\nThat is why my answer for the last \u201cGreat White Hope\u201d was Gentleman Gerry Cooney. In 1982 the heavyweight champion was Larry Holmes. He was a great undefeated champion at the time. One disadvantage for Holmes was the fact that he followed Muhammad Ali as the champion. He was a great fighter but he was not Ali, and his attempts at trying to be another Ali as a person seemed to always fall flat. The American press had a very contentious relationship with him, and, as a result, he always got bad press, regardless of how great he was. In comes Gerry Cooney, an attractive White, young (24), undefeated power puncher, who had knocked out Ken Norton and Ron Lyle in the first round and stopped Jimmy Young in four rounds.\nCooney vs. Holmes was a boxing promoter\u2019s dream, and Don King got there first. He may have even began saying what everybody was thinking: Gerry was the \u201cGreat White Hope.\u201d But Cooney\u2019s camp stirred the pot, too, stating that Gerry was \u201cnot the White man but the right man.\u201d The commercial market ate it up. When a fight date was set, Cooney got premium shaving cream TV commercials as well as other perks. He got favorable publicity. His purse was equal to that of Holmes, $10 million, although there was no reason for it. On the night of the fight, a century of boxing tradition was broken by introducing the champion (Holmes) first and the challenger (Cooney) last. The race card was in the atmosphere at many closed circuit locations, if not at the fight itself.\nIn the actual fight, Cooney briefly hit the canvas in the second round. After that he fought well, but he kept throwing punches below Holmes\u2019 belt. (Holmes is reported to have urinated blood after the fight). The referee never warned Gerry for low punches. Outside of that, Cooney fought a good fight, but Holmes fought a great fight. By the late rounds, Holmes was engaged in target practice with his hard right hands. The referee wisely stopped the fight in the 13th round, as it looked like Cooney was ready to go down.\nGerry did not fight for two years after that. He had the makings of a great champion but some thought that he was brought along too fast. Gerry would eventually say that his handlers had no interest in developing him as a fighter. Gerry never embraced the \u201cGreat White Hope\u201d mantle. Like Jeffries, it was thrust upon him by people who had their own agenda. He is now co-host of a boxing radio show and does a great job. Cooney is quite the humble man. He and Holmes are great friends now. I have heard both of them in public gatherings refuse to criticize the other, saying \u201cWe\u2019re friends now.\u201d\nNow rated as one of the greatest heavyweight boxers of all time, Holmes would later say that his fight with Cooney was one of the toughest he ever had. This was one time the dark side didn\u2019t win. Holmes and Cooney have the greatest respect and admiration for each other because of that fight.", "I hate the term \u201cgreat white hope\u201d because of what it meant historically, and the racist overtones that persist to this day.\nHaving said that, in terms of American boxing, my friend Keith Scott is right as usual, and the last two \u201cgreat white hopes\u201d were Gerry Cooney and Tommy Morrison. I will add a third and earlier white hope though, whose name has faded with the mists of time, Duane Bobick.\nCREDIT PICTURE JO SPORTS\nIn chronological order:\nDuane Bobick\nDuane Bobick, born on August 24, 1950, was at one time a genuine contender for the heavyweight championship. As an amateur he won the gold medal at the 1971 Pan American Games and fought at the 1972 Olympics. 6\u20323\u2033 with an 82 inch reach, and weighing 215 pounds, he knocked out Mike Weaver in the amateurs, and outpointed Larry Holmes. He thought he would win a Gold Medal in the Olympics in 1972, but the great Cuban heavyweight Teofilo Stevenson stopped him in a dead even fight in the 3rd round.\nOn the surface, his amateur record, 93\u201310, with 60 knockouts, and victories over Mike Weaver and Larry Holmes, gave hope of a coming champion. But I remember at the time thinking about his two losses by knockout in the amateurs to Ron Lyle, one of which had him unconscious in the ring for over five minutes, and believing those were a harbinger of problems for him in the pros.\nWith some fanfare, Bobick turned professional in 1973, having decided to devote himself to boxing. He trained into superb shape, and managed to convince Joe Frazier to train and manage him.\nBy 1975, he had managed victories over Mike Weaver, and #10 contender Larry Middleton, and serious buzz had begun about his prospects. 1976 saw him beat fringe contender Chuck Wepner, and rise to #4 contender. In early 1977, he rose to the #3 contender. That was the height of his career.\nFrazier had arranged a tenative agreement for him to fight Muhammad Ali for the title in 1976, but it had fallen through, and so instead, Joe arranged for him to fight his old friend Ken Norton, who after George Foreman retirement, was ranked #1 in the world. If he beat Norton, he got a shot at the title, and the great white hope thing was in full bloom.\nBut the Norton fight was the end of the great white hope status for Duane Bobick and the end of any serious hope of a title. He was 38\u20130 with 32 knockouts that day in May in 1977 when he met Ken Norton in Madison Square Garden. A swarmer, Bobick was, like his trainer Joe Frazier, slow to warm up. He never got the chance to warm up against Norton. 58 seconds into the first round the referee stopped the fight after a devastating overhand right from Norton sent Bobick reeling across the ring, and a follow up hit him in the Adam\u2019s apple. Up at 9, he was obviously in no shape to continue, and the referee stopped the fight.\nBobick was done as a serious contender, though he ranked #5 in 1978, a knockout at the hands of Kallie Knoetze finished him completely as a contender. Losses by knockout to rising star John Tate and journeyman George Chaplain sent him into retirement.\nBobick returned to his home in Minnesota and worked in paper mills before an industrial accident nearly killed him in 1997. Both his arms were caught and crushed between huge paper rolls being rotated in the paper mill. He only barely avoided amputation after complex surgery to re-attach muscles and tendons and repair massive skin and bone trauma. After that he went into coaching and public speaking, using his celebrity to help others. In November 2006, Bobick was elected as a city councilman.\nUnfortunately, as with so many, pugilistic dementia ended Bobick\u2019s public life. Bobick suffers from chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE) and has to be cared for full-time by his wife.\nGerry Cooney\nAbout the time Duane Bobick retired in 1979, the next great white hope, Gerry Cooney, had entered the rankings at #9 contender.\nGerald Arthur Cooney was born on August 4, 1956, six years after Bobick, is best remembered for his title challenge to Larry Holmes in 1982, though he fought again for a title in 1987.\nWinning the New York Golden Gloves, the 6\u20326\u2033 Cooney was 55\u20133 as an amateur, and rose quickly in the paid ranks when he turned professional in 1977, entering the top ten two years later. With an 81 inch reach, and a devastating left hook, Cooney was 25\u20130 by 1982, with 23 knockouts, when he challenged Larry Holmes for the WBC heavyweight championship.\nCooney had knocked out Ron Lyle in the first round in 1980, and stopped the always tough Jimmy Young with a TKO. In 1981 Cooney knocked out Ken Norton, and the stage was set for him to meet Holmes.\nRon Lyle and Ken Norton were both powerful and skilled heavyweights, but both were destroyed in the 1st round by Cooney in amazing displays of punching power. There is an argument today that both men were past their prime in these contests but there\u2019s no getting around the fact that these two, normally very durable and tough heavyweights, were totally destroyed.\nMany boxing writers, and much of the public, was so amazed by his performances against Lyle and Norton that they predicted he would just walk into the ring and knock Holmes out the same way. Holmes however, had other ideas and was not in the least bit concerned about Cooney, saying he would expose him in the ring as a pretender.\nThe racial hype prior to the fight was truly ugly. Cooney\u2019s management milked the great white hope theme for all it was worth. A telephone line was set up in Cooney\u2019s dressing room, so that President Ronald Reagan could wish him good luck. Holmes was ignored. Then, just prior to the opening bell, Holmes, against all boxing tradition, was introduced first despite being the defending champion.\nBut the disrespect enraged Holmes, and he made Cooney pay for it. Holmes had Cooney reeling around the ring in the first round, and knocked him down in the second, but the big man was game, and fought on, landing some terrific shots on Holmes. Larry would tell Ring in later years \u201c\u201cGerry was much better than I thought he was and I tell him that to this day, when he fought Kenny Norton, I didn\u2019t think he was going to win that fight but he took Kenny out in a few seconds\u2026\u201d\nCooney was completely exhausted by Round 13, and was hit by Holmes with a brutal series of head shots, preceded by a right lead. Cooney fell into the ropes and his trainer, Victor Valle, entered the ring to rescue Cooney, forcing referee Mills Lane to end the fight. Incredibly, if Cooney hadn\u2019t had three points deducted for low blows, two judges would have had the challenger ahead after 12 rounds.\nThat was the end for Cooney as a serious title contender, though he would fight Mike Spinks for the title in 1987, in one of Spinks two title defenses. KO\u2019s by Spinks, he was KO\u2019s again by the returning Old George Foreman and retired.\nThe highest Cooney ever rose in the rankings was #2 in 1980 and 1981.\nIronically, he and Holmes became friends in later years, and remain so to this day.\nCooney\u2019s after boxing life is happier than Bobick\u2019s. Cooney is deeply involved in J.A.B., the first union for boxers, and has worked as an analyst for fights. He lives with his wife and two of their children in New Jersey.\nOur last great white hope is Tommy Morrison\nTommy Morrison's life and death was - and is - a cautionary tale, a tragedy, a tragedy of wasted talent, wasted time, and a wasted life.\nBorn in 1969, 13 years after Gerry Cooney, and a distant relative of John Wayne\u2019s, for a time, the \u201cDuke,\u201d as Morrison was known, was considered a genuine contender.\nMorrison claimed an amateur record of 222-20, and had steadily improved his skills as an amateur. He had first rate fundamental skills, according to Lennox Lewis, and others. What he did not have were the \"three D's\" as Manny Steward used to say, discipline, direction, and devotion to his craft. Tommy made the post-Rooney Tyson look like a piker for partying. Tommy partied 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, 365 days a year, and it not only stunted and eventually stopped his career, it also killed him.\nA horde of writers, other fighters, Morrison\u2019s family, and his manager, Bill Cayton, were constantly exasperated by Tommy's devotion to women, drink and drugs. Morrison's life, and his complete lack of professionalism, and party lifestyle were detailed religiously in \"The Tommy \"The Duke\" Morrison Story\" by Charles H. Hood.\nHood provides riveting details from Tommy Morrison's wife, and grandparents, parents, brothers and sister. Hood\u2019s biography of Tommy Morrison is based upon personal interviews with Dawn Morrison Brady, her detailed journal entries that spanned over 13 years, and early life tales as told by Tommy\u2019s grandparents, parents, brothers and sister.\nAs his mother wryly said, \"nobody could ever tell Tommy anything. He lived the way he wanted, and it killed him.\" Bill Cayton said \"he could have been great...\"\nGeorge Foreman said of Morrison, \"\u201cHe was a good puncher, he could hit, and he moved his head well,\u201d Foreman said. \u201cHe had a good style. I thought he\u2019d have a great career.\u201d\nLennox Lewis, who defeated Morrison, was quick to praise him, calling him \"one of the hardest punchers I ever met.\" Lewis also said, \"he has talent, he doesn't have discipline,\" and he is not the only fighter who says it. Ray Mercer, one of three men who beat Morrison, claimed that Morrison hit harder than Lennox Lewis, \"but he doesn't train,\" said Mercer, \"and in this business it isn't enough to hit hard or have talent, you have to use it and work on it.\"\nAnd Tommy did not work on it, or anything, according to his manager and family, except partying.\nMorrison himself said repeatedly that his \"sexually promiscuous lifestyle, along with gun and drug crimes,\" (his words), resulting in jail and prison time, sabotaged what might have been a far brighter career. When he retired the first time, after the HIV finding in Nevada, Morrison said at a news conference he'd never fight again, blaming his plight on a \"permissive, fast and reckless lifestyle.''\nHis lifestyle never changed, though, even when he stepped away from the ring.\nMorrison didn't train, he drank, he took drugs, he slept with every woman he could find, and he got HIV and refused to treat it. At one point in 1996 Morrison was married to two women at the same time, Dawn Freeman and Dawn Gilbert, while having encounters with hundreds more. (Morrison claimed he beat Wilt Chamberlain's record of sleeping with 20,000 women, and said he could even remember some of them).\nStardom, Foreman said \u201ccan be tough. One day, no one pays you any attention. The next, you\u2019re this good-looking, popular guy that everyone wants a piece of and your whole world explodes. And if you\u2019re not ready for it, it can take you on a ride that takes you quicker than you want to the last day of your life.\u201d\n\u201cI didn\u2019t know much about his personal life, and didn\u2019t get into it,\u201d Foreman said. But he knew that Tommy's personal life sabatoged his talent, and ruined his career.\nAnd the saddest part was, Tommy was basically a good guy. George Foreman recalled how, in a pre-fight press conference, Morrison took Foreman\u2019s words and converted them to rib the former heavyweight champion about his expanding waistline. \u201cThe one thing about George is that he\u2019s got two chins, so you\u2019re not sure which one to hit,\u201d Morrison said.\nSaid Foreman: \u201cI thought that was so funny, we rehearsed it so we could use the same exchange at the next day\u2019s press conference. The thing about Tommy was he was just a good guy.\u201d\nMorrison was proud he was a distant relative of John Wayne. But the problem was he lived his whole life like he was in the Wild West. His mother gave him his first tattoo. And his father gave him his first woman -- at a strip club when Tommy was 14.\nThey entered him, as an eighth-grader, in \"tough man\" contests. In other words, his parents essentially signed him up for bar fights. That's how he made his name. That and setting fire to his high school football field when he was cut from the team.\nTommy well and truly lost his mind after he contacted HIV. It was a February morning in 1996, shortly after signing a $38.5 million new contract, and he was 27, when he found out he had HIV. He freely and happily admitted later that after a talk with Magic Johnson, who told him the key was listen to his doctor's, that he did the opposite. \"I partied away!\" said Morrison.\nHis family assumed he contracted HIV from a dirty steroid needle, but no one knows for sure, because Tommy declined to talk about it, ever. Before the turn of the new millennium, he bought a cave, (yes, a cave), convinced that the world was coming to an end at the stroke of midnight on Jan. 1, 2000. That's where he slept on Dec. 31, 1999. Morrison also claimed that HIV was a conspiracy by the government.\nIn August 2013, Morrison's mother told ESPN: Serving sports fans. Anytime. Anywhere.\nthat her son had full-blown AIDS. \"He's too far gone,\" she said. \"He's in the end stages. That's it.\"\nTommy Morrison died on September 1, 2013, at a hospital in Omaha, Nebraska. According to his death certificate, he died from cardiac arrest stemming from a blood infection known as Pseudomonas Aeruginosa Septicemia, which unfortunately is a common cause of death in HIV-infected patients.\nTommy Morrison entered the rankings at #9 in 1993, and remained #9 in 1994. He was unranked from 1995 on, for all his knockouts. He ended his career 48\u20133 with 42 KO\u2019s.\nTalent is not enough. In any field, and especially in boxing, talent has be, as Mayweather says, polished and developed. Tommy had an abundance of talent. He had no intention of, and never did, polish and develop it. He discovered the joys of stardom, and partying, and that was that.\nCREDITS:\nRING for contender rankings\nBoxrec for statistics\nRing interview on Holmes-Cooney Larry Holmes: Gerry Cooney was \u2018a helluva fighter\u2019 - The Ring\nESPN \u201cMorrison's wild ride ended by denial\u201d by Tom Friend Morrison's wild ride ended by denial\nGoing the Distance : The Ken Norton Story by Ken Norton\nLarry Holmes: Against the Odds by Larry Holmes\nThe Tommy \"The Duke\" Morrison Story by Charles H. Hood", "Jess willard", "They fought about 15 years apart. In the early \u201880\u2019s everyone thought that of Gerry Cooney, especially after he knocked out Ron Lyle and Ken Norton. He got a title shot at Larry Holmes in 1982. It\u2019s disgusting now to think that even in the 1980\u2019s a fight had racial overtones but it did. A special phone was installed in Cooney\u2019s dressing room so President Reagan could call him and congratiulate him if he won. No such phone was put in Holmes\u2019 dressing room. Holmes dropped him in the 2nd round, but he got up and gave Holmes a tough fight. It was stopped in the 13th round-Holmes had floored Cooney again and was battering him. Cooney\u2019s manager jumped into the ring and had the referee stop it. Holmes won by TKO. In the \u201890\u2019s there was Tommy Morrison-John Wayne\u2019s grandson. He had a fearsome left hook, but he had kind of a glass jaw. He starred in Rocky IV, and some other TV shows. He beat James Tillis, Pinklon Thomas, Carl Williams, Razor Ruddock and got a questionable decision over George Foreman. He was also KO\u2019d by Ray Mercer, Michael Bentt and Lennox Lewis. He retired in 1996 when the Nevada boxing commission reported he tested positive for HIV. He went on a downward spiral of drug use and not taking his HIV medication and died at age 44 in 2013.", "Last time I truly felt the great white hope vibe was Tommy Morrison.\nMaybe it\u2019s because he was regional to my area. Hell, he passed away in a hospital in my city.\nBut he had the racist boomers in my city fired up man. Boxing was big when the Duke fought.\nThe men loved him as much as the ladies and when it was safe to say so it was because he was WHITE.\nI never got the feeling Morrison played that up. Seemed like a decent guy and man could he whack.\nEveryone\u2019s answer could be different of course. But I\u2019ve always been a boxing nut and this is my experience.\nI loved watching him fight. There is a pretty good YouTube documentary that covers his early fights. Some rare footage.", "Tyson Fury", "\u201cGerry Cooney\u201d \u2026enter Larry Holmes", "Well, there\u2019s Tyson Fury right now\u2026.\nAnd the Klitscho Bros were pretty bad ass.", "Tommy Morrison was one of the more notable last of the Great White Hopes, one that garnered significant attention and media hype and one who was often referred to as being the proverbial \u201cGreat White Hope!\u201d\nAnd it\u2019s understandable as to why Morrison was so popular: he had good boxing skills, a very powerful punch, a crowd-pleasing fighting style, and a genial, charismatic personality. It also didn\u2019t hurt that he was the great-grandnephew of the legendary actor John Wayne (whose birthname was Marion Morrison)! So, Morrison was popular for many reasons and subsequently garnered much media attention because of it.\nSure, Tommy had his weaknesses as a fighter, most notably a less-than-reliable chin and limited stamina, issues which cost him in several fights, most notably in his losses to Ray Mercer and Michael Bentt. But technically, Morrison was sound: he had excellent boxing fundamentals, threw powerful, crisp combinations, and simply knew how to fight \u2014 but his weaknesses prevented him from ever reaching the top, although he came close.\nFurthermore, Morrison\u2019s personal life was often chaotic, one replete with drug and alcohol problems, rampant sexual promiscuity, and a few brief stints in jail/prison. And ultimately, Morrison succumbed to his personal demons and died at a very young age (44) from what is believed to be AIDS-related complications.\nBut for several years during the 1990s, Morrison was a key player in the heavyweight division, a fighter who added a lot of excitement to the game!", "Tommy Morrison, by a long shot. The answer will be simple and straight. Boxing career record: 48 wins 42 wins by TKO 3 loses 1 draw. He was, indeed, a great boxer and the last \u201dgreat white hope\u201d. His only losses we're to three of the best fighters the boxing world had seen: Lennox Lewis and Ray Mercer. He also lost to Michael Bennett who wasn't as the fighter Tommy Morrison. The bout stood as an upset.", "Probably Gerry Cooney, who was billed as such by Don King when he fought Larry Holmes for the heavyweight title in 1982. Cooney came along at a time when the world heavyweight champion had been Black for many years. There were several \u201cgreat white hopes\u201d before Cooney, and one of them, Jerry Quarry, even has it on his tombstone. Quarry and some of the others came close, but never won a recognized belt.\nThe Holmes-Cooney fight was punctuated with some disgusting racist statements and behavior, much of it fueled by King himself to make more money. The two fighters themselves wanted nothing to do with this, although I am certain Holmes resented how easily Cooney became the top contender, when Holmes had struggled for years to get his shot. But when Holmes faced him in the ring, all he said was \u201clet\u2019s have a good fight.\u201d Cooney was outclassed, but fought a courageous fight before being stopped in the 13th round. He and Holmes are close friends today, as many great boxing rivals have become after their ring days ended.\nA decade later, I heard the term used in connection with Tommy Morrison, who was the \u201cbad guy\u201d in one of the Rocky movies and was also a real heavyweight boxer. Morrison did win the WBO title, but at a time when it wasn\u2019t considered a \u201cmajor\u201d belt. This was also in a time when the matter of the race of the world heavyweight champion had ceased being such an issue. Andrew Golota, in one of his attempts to win a title, was victimized by a poor decision and there was no more outrage than there is when a minority fighter gets ripped off.\nNo one would use this silly term today. As a Serbian you well know that the status of \u201ccountry\u201d is a fluid one that changes over the years. For example take Russia. For a long time it competed internationally as part of the Soviet Union - now it is an independent country.\nWhat period of time are we talking about. The last 5 years, 10 years,\nWhat is a satisfactory measure of success. Number of school children enrolled in formal sport activity? The number of FIFA World Cup\u2019s the nation has won?\nThere are probably more issues than I have listed but you get the idea?\nSo here is what I decided to measure:\nThe number of medals (regardless of colour) that each country has won in the modern Olympic Games divided by the 100,000th of the population.\nI used the data from these two Wikipedia websites:\nAll-time Olympic Games medal table - Wikipedia\nList of countries and dependencies by population - Wikipedia\nI used MS Excel to do the calculation.\nHere is what I found:\nThe most successful country is Norway with an index of 9.7 medals per 100,000 population\nSerbia has an index of 0.2 (This is a middle of the pack ranking).\nMy top countries in order of success were Norway, Sweden, Bahamas, Austria, Australia, Belgium, Great Britain, Canada, France , Italy, Germany, Belarus, United States, Poland, South Korea, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Japan, Russia\nNow it is at this point in the answer that I have to confess that I did not complete all the countries tabulations because I ran out of time and I also think that it is something anyone can do for themselves. So I leave it to others to troll through the data and see if there is a country that can beat Norway\u2019s index. There may be one of the smaller countries that has won a few medals and thus gained a high index.\nAs I said at the beginning there are issues with whatever way you tackle this question. One that hasn\u2019t been mentioned already is that it is teams and not exactly nations that compete at the OG - for the majority they are synonymous but issues with for example Russia means that they have probably been underrated by my methodology.\nYou may wonder why Norway and Sweden are at the top of this list. The team can travel and compete against other school\u2019s teams, but these are referred to as exhibition matches. Basically, people take it seriously, but not too seriously, and there are no scholarships or restrictions. Not all school have club sports. Most schools do have intramural sports, where groups of students (and even faculty/staff, in some cases) can form a team and compete in low-contact sports.\nIf you\u2019re speaking of NCAA or NAIA competitive teams, in your regular fourth year, you should have eligibility, but as for whether you\u2019d qualify for a fifth year\u2026 I have no idea. The Ashes are regarded as being held by the team that most recently won the Test series. If the test series is drawn, the team that currently holds the Ashes retains the trophy. It is traditionally of five Tests, hosted in turn by England and Australia at least once every two years.\nThe match : It\u2019s 1882 and on their tour to England that year the Australians played just one Test, at the Oval in London. England lost final 4 wickets for just 7 runs while chasing 85 runs for victory and fell 8 runs short. An astonished Oval crowd fell silent, struggling to believe that England could possibly have lost to a colony on home soil.\nThis is Australia\u2019s first Test win on English soil. And then The term \u201cAshes\u201doriginated in a mock notice published in a British newspaper, The Sporting Times. It stated that English cricket had died, and \"the body will be cremated and the ashes taken to Australia\".\nThe reason for such outrage by British newspaper being England was in a winning position and lost from an impossible position.\nThe Ashes urn is a small urn made of terracotta and standing 10.5 cm high, believed to contain the ashes of a burnt cricket bail. This is presented to the captain of the team which retains the trophy at the end of each Test Series.\nI would like to also write briefly about my favorite Ashes Test Series ever (Considered to be the Greatest Ever as well) in the two decades I have been following. It is 2005 Ashes series in England and the Ashes were held with Australia as they were the recent victors.\nEngland have not lost a Test series at home to their arch-rivals since 2001. However, England didn\u2019t win Ashes series for nearly 19 years. To start of, England lost the first Test at Lord's by 239 runs. From here, it seemed impossible to win the Test Series and get back the famous urn back to home. Good news follows for second test, Australia fast bowler Glenn McGrath was ruled out of the second Test at Edgbaston after treading on a ball during practice on the morning of the match.\nEngland took charge, Flintoff starred with both and ball and Australia were dead at 175-8, chasing 282 for victory, a home win looked assured. However, Australia being Australia came back with Brett lee adding useful runs along with Shane Warne and unlikely Kasprowicz. England held their nerve and Steve Harmison dismissed Michael Kasprowicz to give England victory by a mere two runs.\nA pic that says a lot about cricket being Gentlemen game and the sportsmanship spirit. Flintoff later told \u201d\u201cI was taught as a kid always respect the opposition first and celebrate after, which I did. I went over to Brett Lee and shook his hand and there\u2019s that picture, where I whisper in his ear: \u2018It\u2019s 1-1, son.\u2019\u201d\nThe third Test was drawn and England survived a brilliant four-wicket burst from leg-spin great Shane Warne to win the fourth Test at Trent Bridge. Australia still have the chance to retain the Ashes if they win the final test by leveling the series (2\u20132) and England were in danger of defeat on the last day at the Oval until Kevin Pietersen's breathtaking 158 and a fine fifty from Ashes Giles rescued them following a top-order collapse.\nFinally, England retain the Ashes, A summer that will never be forgotten.\nA special mention to 1981: Botham's Ashes, rarely has one man done as much to win an Ashes as Ian Botham in 1981.\n1948: Australia's 'Invincibles' when Don Bradman captained Australia and won it 4\u20130 comprehensively.\n1974/5: Lillee and Thomson, when the speed guns run riot against English batting line up to win the series 4\u20131.\n1932/33: 'Bodyline', The most controversial Ashes series of them all, which saw batsmen having to defend themselves rather than their stumps and rules of cricket needed a change. It worked to the extent England won the Ashes 4-1, was condemned as \"unsporting\" by Australian officials.\nIn total, there have been 71 Ashes series: Australia have won 33, England 32 and six series have been drawn and Australia currently holds the trophy.", "The Ashes is a Test Cricket series played between England and Australia. The Ashes are regarded as being held by the team that most recently won the Test series. If the test series is drawn, the team that currently holds the Ashes retains the trophy. The term originated in a satirical obituary published in a British newspaper, The Sporting Times, immediately after Australia's 1882 Victory at The Oval, its first Test win on English soil. The obituary stated that English cricket had died, and \"the body will be cremated and the ashes taken to Australia\".\nThe mythical ashes immediately became associated with the 1882\u201383 series played in Australia, before which the English captain Ivo Bligh\nhad vowed to \"regain those ashes\". The English media therefore dubbed the tour the quest to regain the Ashes.\nThe Ashes\nThe Ashes urn, made of terracott and about 15 cm (6 inches) tall, is reputed to contain the ashes of a burnt Cricket Bail.\nCountries\nAustralia\nEngland\nAdministrator\nICC\nFormat\nTest Cricket\nFirst edition\n1882\u201383\n(Australia)\nLatest edition\n2019\n(England)\nNext edition\n2021\u201322\n(Australia)\nTournament format\n5-match series\nNumber of teams\n2\nCurrent trophy holder\nAustralia\nMost successful\nAustralia (33 series wins)\nMost runs\nSir Donald Bradman (5,028)\nMost wickets\nShane Warne (195)\nMy first answer over Quora. He was shocked to learn all he had to do was keep standing of the rest of the fight,. My corner he basically said told him he was behind on points. Also I despite now Hearns talking about his hands I guess in the fight with Hagler, he also at the time sort of blacked Stewart for having him run in some sand dunes or something, and wear out his legs. Regardless of the way Tyson left the sport of boxing, he will go down in history as one of the greatest heavyweight boxers in the World.", "Ok, seeing as no one is actually answering the question (with the exception ofJason Anthony), I'll put in my analysis.\nCoincidentally, I rewatched the entire fight just last week and so it's fresh in the mind.\nRound 1\nAs Jason Anthony has stated, Tyson took the first round. And this was not due to any quality punches landed or any dominance, but rather because Mike Tyson came off the blocks quicker than Lewis, was busier and more aggressive. Emanuel Steward, Lewis's trainer, would shout at him throughout the fight to box on the outside, use the jab and 'stay well away from that *********! Don't get into an exchange!\u201d. It's therefore likely that Lewis used the first round to cautiously evaluate his rival.\nRound 2\nMike Tyson came out again trying to replicate the first round performance. But the Briton was wiser now, and started to clinch Tyson and lean his 250lb+ weight on the shorter man every time Tyson tried to come on the inside. Tyson grew visibly frustrated as he could neither land his main weapon - the left hook - nor get to his favoured mid-range distance without being clinched. Lewis bagged that round.\nRounds 3\u20137\nHaving found a template that worked, Lewis stuck to it, and also began to find a home for his straight right to Tyson's head. Due to Tyson still trying to land the left hook, there was no protection at all on his left side as Lennox Lewis began to land one powerful right after another. I was amazed at the strength of Tyson's chin!\nBut the referee did not protect Tyson from Lewis's constant holding and leaning and despite a few ineffective warnings did not deduct any points.\nTyson's corner were imploring him to let his hands go and swarm the Englishman, but he did not have the agility of his earlier years to dart in and out of range. The trainer warned him that he would stop the fight if the punishment continued. Emanuel Steward, meanwhile, instructed Lewis to stick to his guns and not get drawn into a firefight.\nHowever, by this stage the American posed only a limited threat. Frustrated by his inability to land the left hook, he appeared to switch in mid fight to a stance favouring the right hook, and indeed he landed a powerful right on Lewis's left jaw in one of the middle rounds. But Lewis looked quite unharmed.\nTyson had swelling above both eyes by this point.\nLewis won all rounds from 3 to 7.\nTyson found his left hook ineffective against Lewis\nLewis landed the straight right any time he wanted to\nRound 8\nThe coup de gr\u00e2ce came in the eighth round by predictable means.\nTyson looked confused, inept and without a viable war strategy. Lewis was still patient with his jab and continued to land the powerful straight right.\nAnd it was one of these blows that caught Tyson flush and sent him crashing to the canvass to end one of the the most embarrassingly one sided bouts of world championship heavyweight boxing.", "That was so long ago but I believe I did give him one or two rounds but I had Lewis comfortably ahead when I believe he finally knocked Tyson out I think the 8th round", "lennox beat the shit out of mike. Fanboys get so wrapped up in the persona of this mythic not so existent Champion they bend reality make excuses without number, and view his Boxing career thru very rose colored glasses.The true hard to realize facts are that Iron Mike was always going to have problems with two kinds of fighter the big strong heavyweight with a jab( Lewis and Douglas) and the brutal infighter( Holyfield, Joe Frazier) who kept him on inside and just roughed him up The Cus D\u2019Amato Peek a Boo was not a defensive masterpiece by a genius( it was for flawed Heavyweights like Patterson and Tyson, Patterson weak chin, Tyson short no reach) Reason Tyson starting loosing wasn\u2019t lack of Rooney it was lack of Training to be able to use such a high energy system", "As usual with the never was a boxing coach, he gave you never was fantasies instead of facts. Today it is Mike Tyson's turn to get lied about.\nMike Tyson did not duck Lennox Lewis for 10 years. While Lennox's size, fundamentals, sound jab and power punching would have always been problematic, it would have been a much closer, if not different, fight had they met early in their careers - a fact Lewis cheerfully acknowledges!\nFirst of all, Mike was best at a fighting weight of around 215. He came into the Lewis fight at 234, the heaviest of his career, and his speed, and movement, were gone. Once a fabulously conditioned volume punching speed demon, Mike was a relatively slow, fat, one shot puncher.\nA young Rooney-trained Tyson, at 215, would have been a completely different fighter, and Lewis acknowledged that.\nLennox said, \"Mike at the age of 19 ruled the world, but like a fine wine, I came along later on and now I'm the ruling man.\"\nTyson, although a year younger than Lewis, began boxing professionally 4 years earlier in 1985. Lewis, who won a Gold Medal in the 1988 Olympics, started in 1989.\nBut what if Lewis had gone pro in 1985 or so, instead of maturing and waiting for the Olympics? He would have been ready for Mike by 1989, when Tyson was at the peak of his career, when he - as Mike said - \"I was the best I ever was, or would be, when I faced Mike Spinks.\"\nEmmanuel Steward, who trained Lennox Lewis after his stunning KO defeat by Oliver McCall, who Steward had trained for that fight, said he believed a prime Lewis still could have defeated a prime Tyson - but he acknowledged prime Mike's speed and intensity. He felt Lewis's sheer size and power would have still triumphed - but it would not have been an easy fight.\nWhen the never was says says the fight took over 10 years to put together because Mike knew he would lose, that is simply not so. Unfortunately, as usual, the never was a coach also never checked a thing in boxing history.\nLennox did not start boxing as a professional until over 4 years and 3 months later than Tyson, despite being a year older. Their careers, because of Lewis's far later start, and Mike forced exile while he was in prison, simply did not overlap for most of their respective careers, and by the time they did, Mike was a very fat shadow of the old Iron Mike.\nLewis was not ready for a top contender until late in 1992, when he met Razor Ruddock. That takes another three years out of their fighting during the same period. Mike was out of boxing while in prison, which further reduces the time. Mike not return until 1995, and he was in no shape to face Lewis just returning from 4 years off.\nMike was never really Mike again after he returned from prison. He was not even in good fighting form of any kind - and certainly absolutely nothing resembling what he had been in his prime. But he had gotten in at least enough shape to fight by 1997 when he faced Holyfield, and promptly lost twice. Mike then took another year and a half off, and that left only 3 years before he faced Lewis.\nTo say Mike ducked Lewis or did not want to make the fight with Lewis for a decade is simply ignoring reality. Mike was out of boxing for almost 6 years out of the ten from 1992, when Lewis became a top contender, and when they met in 2002!\nEmmanuel Steward, one of history's great trainers, believed that Lewis was always too big, too strong, for Tyson. But he also acknowledged that a young, Rooney trained Tyson had been a different, focused, fabulously in shape, speed and intensity driven champion. Lewis said it best, at 19 and for three years, Mike was King, but Lennox came along later, and became the Man.\nAnd those are the real facts, not never was alternate reality ones!", "I gave Tyson the first round. I believe they have 64 teams represented to a championship from which eight are admitted to the College World Series. Double elimination. Is the basis through which teams are admitted and selected following which eight qualify (advance to) the College World Series. The entire tournament is double elimination. Eight are admitted to the last pairing. All eight are logistical represented within the championship.", "Depends on how many teams, but let's say it's four (I'm stealing this from NCAA baseball regionals which are four-team double elimination). The four teams pair off in the first round. In the second round, the two winners play and the two losers play. The loser of that second game, call them team D, is eliminated. Team A won both games and awaits the survivor. Teams B and C are 1\u20131 and play each other in an elimination game. After Team B wins that, they must beat Team A twice to win the tournament. Team A needs only one win to take the title.\nSix-team brackets are more complex and generally include winners playing losers in later rounds without the must-win-two situation. Eight-team brackets can be done two ways: One is two parallel four-team brackets with the winners meeting at the end; the other also involves winners playing losers in later rounds without the must-win-two."], "topic_list": ["Tournaments", "Sports"], "view_list": [22, 27], "create_time": "Apr 23, 2020", "no_of_follower": 2, "question_author": "Roksana Parvin Yasmin", "upvote_list": [0, 1], But the players didn\u2019t like having to drop everything on the PGA Tour or the European Tour for 2\u20133 weeks in order to travel to different places, so the events ended up being held primarily in the US or in US favored time zones.\nThe WGC events are currently:\nWGC Mexico Championship\nWGC Dell Technologies Match Play\nWGC FedEx St. Jude Invitational\nWGC HSBC Champions\nTiger Woods has dominated these events winning HALF of the first 32 events held. He has 18 WGC wins.\nEarlier this year, he was fighting his bad back so he was not entered in the WGC Mexico event. The WGC Match Play event for this season was supposed to be in late March and it was cancelled. The Invitational is scheduled now for the end of July. More so than other players, when the ball is set to the outside hitter they are expected to score.\nHere are the core responsibilities and traits of a good Outside hitter:\nQuick to get the ball\nExceptional ball control to pass balls (they play a heavy defensive role even though they are hitters)\nShrewdness to successfully get past blockers (high walls will always be there for the outside)\nPowerful and quick arm swing\nExceptional blocking abilities (playing the front left side of the court means you need to be able to block and be efficient at it)\nObservant of opponent players\u2019 positions (understanding to read the attackers and also be able to quickly identify open spots on the court is essential for successful blocks and attacks)\nExcellent jumping abilities (here\u2019s a good and free beginner volleyball jump training program\nyou can follow)\nSo given these traits and responsibilities, you can reverse engineer the perfect outside hitter. Getting to the point of \u201cperfection\u201d though is more easily said than done of course.\nSo what can you do to continually practice these things?\nPractice lots of hitting, passing, and blocking drills. I am not sure what type of situation you\u2019re in (do you play for a team, are you practicing solo, etc.) so I will let you find the drills that suit you most (youtube has a ton of great resources for this).\nOnce you have practiced a ton of drills and are given more time to develop the key traits, it\u2019s time to embed these traits into your body and make them instincts. The only way to do this is to play in official games. When I say official I just mean competitive 6v6 games. powdered gloves aren\u2019t really banned (well not for the \u201caverage Joe\u201d anyway), they\u2019re just not allowed for use in medical facilities like hospitals or doctors offices (with the exception of powdered radiologist\u2019s gloves), and by medical professionals that perform outside of those facilities like EMT\u2019s. Anyone else (like you or I, provided that you aren\u2019t a medical professional) is allowed to use them. If you want to wear powdered gloves while you clean the bathroom, plant the garden, work on the car, chop onions and garlic, paint a room, or clean the cat\u2019s litter boxes, knock yourself out.\nSo why are they banned? Apparently there is some risk of the powder becoming airborne (causing lung inflammation) or ending up on and/or in the patient through other contact and causing an allergic reaction. Also, there is supposedly a possibility of the powder causing wound inflammation and scarring post surgery. I have no idea how, how often, or why this happens, or what the powder is made of, but it seems the FDA thought the problem was serious enough that they needed to stop medical professionals from using them.
