He hustle every play and doesn\u2019t brash too much when things are or aren\u2019t going so well. He brings power and speed, he\u2019s not the most flashiest of player, bur he does what needs to be done. He always makes heads up plays, such as during one play as a runner, the hitter has hit a high chopper to first while he was on second. So instead of just stopping at third, he continued to hustle around third to score. From the broadcast, Harry Kalas would make the statement that would stick for the rest of his career, \u2018Chase Utley, you are the man\u2019 No doubt that he makes these heads up play to make the team better. Or plays like in the World Series in 2008, which there was a ground ball up the middle against the speedy batter with a runner in scoring position. He fields the ball towards the second base bag, he knew that he wasn\u2019t going to get the runner. Instead of trying to throwing the runner out, he faked the throw and threw the runner out to prevent the tying run. One of the best heads up plays.\nPhillies-Most hated-Scott Rolen: Scott really was a good player for the Phillies and played some great years during probably the most lean years with the organization. He was a good hitter and a tremendous third baseman, probably the best third baseman since Mike Schmidt. A couple of years before free agency, the Phillies offered an extension to Rolen in order to allow him to play with the great infield with Rollins, Utley, and Howard during the mid-2000\u2019s until 2010, except he refused. During the trade deadline of 2002, the Phillies would trade Rolen to the St. Louis Cardinals. Than, he made comments saying how St. Louis was baseball heaven, which of course was a shot at the Phillies and their fanbase. Once he got traded and made his return to Philadelphia, he would get a great warm reception of boos from the Philly faithful for the rest of his career. For example, core strength, agility, quick feet (speed ladder drills), explosive strength are needed for both football or boxing. Similarly for weight training most athletes do the same compound strength exercises.\nof course there are technical specifics in both. and some sports will require more of one than the other etc.. But I\u2019d say at least 60% of your strength and conditioning program will complement both sports and keep you well conditioned for good performance regardless.\nthis is an example of a weeks Strength and conditioning program that would vary from week to week -\nDay 1 - strength training (compound) & speed ladder drills\nday 2 - swimming\nday 3 - rest\nday 4 - core strengthening and cardio\nday 5 - explosive drills and agility training\nday 6 & 7 - rest\nOne way of managing your time is that you could dedicate 1 week just for strength and conditioning (example above) then week 2 just play football (soccer) and week 3 just do boxing. I would not recommend switching sports in the same week as you may lose momentum. While you play football and do boxing this would also include conditioning drills that are more specific to those sports -\nthis way in each three week cycle you\u2019re staying in good condition and giving a descent amount of time to both sports. I\u2019m not a big fan of doing just one sport for a few weeks then switching to another for a few weeks. While focusing one a single sport for large amounts of time may give you good momentum as good progress allot of this can be lost if you don\u2019t play that sport for extended periods of time while you do the other. So while you may be training hard for both sports your progress will be slow and won\u2019t reflect the hard work you put in. Changing from week to week means you\u2019re not leaving such long periods of time between sports hence whatever progress you made will remain fresh and allow you to build up and improve.\nanother good trick to get more training in would be to wake up early. If you wake up at 5am, you can get a good work out and another one after you finish your day to day stuff. allot of professional atheletes who also work jobs use this method to get enough training in.\ngood luck \ud83e\udd18", "This is probably not going to be much help but it\u2019s worth considering, every time you misplace a pass or cock up a tackle, just punch the opponent nearest to you, just make sure the ref doesn\u2019t see you or it will be a very short training session.", "No, no, no.\nWrong two sports.\nIce hockey and Boxing.\nPlease\u2026.", "By doing road work (jogging) you can train for both sports simultaneously.", "Just by doing it."], "topic_list": ["Sports Training", "Playing Football", "Soccer in the United States", "Boxing (sport)", "Football Players (soccer)", "Training", "Professional Sports", "Sports", "Association Football", "Fitness"], "view_list": [41, 77, 71, 16, 4], "create_time": "Apr 27, 2020", "no_of_follower": 1, "question_author": "Aman Manik", "upvote_list": [1, 1, 0, 0, 0], "question_title": "How can you train for both soccer and boxing at the same time?", "respond_collected": 5, "no_of_view": "773", "name_list": ["Sam van Lekker", "Steve Leyden", "Tom Stagliano", "Eloy Haughton", "David Culp"], "date_list": ["Apr 27, 2020", "Apr 27, 2020", "Apr 27, 2020", "Apr 27, 2020", "Apr 27, 2020"]}, "65": {"ans_list": ["Club teams and intramurals?
